questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with complaints of dull pain over the right lower abdomen for the past 2  months. CT scan revealed a pseudomyxoma peritonei. Which of the following is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and findings confirms the diagnosis of pseudomyxoma peritonei. It is associated with mucinous cystadenoma.

Pseudomyxoma peritonei (PMP) is a rare clinical entity characterized by diffuse intra-abdominal gelatinous and mucoid material on peritoneal surfaces. Spontaneous perforation of a mucinous cystadenoma leads to implantation of low-grade malignant tumor cells in the peritoneum.

However, the most common cause of pseudomyxoma peritonei is carcinoma of the appendix.

Diagnosis is by CT, MRI, and laparoscopy. Even after the removal of the ovarian tumor, these cells continue to secrete mucin. Recurrence rates are high.

questions.text: In a town, there are 2500 live births within 6 months. During the same period, 5 women died due to peripartum infection, 5 women died due to electrocution, 2 died due to obstructed labour and 3 died due to postpartum haemorrhage. What is the maternal mortality ratio?
questions.solution:
MMR = Number of maternal deaths in a period x 100,000 (or 1000)/Number of live births in the same period

In this scenario, only 10 women died due to causes related to pregnancy (5-peripartum infection,2- obstructed labour and 3-postpartum haemorrhage). Only they can be included in the statistics.

So, MMR here = 10 x 100000/2500 = 400 per 100,000 live births.

questions.text: What is the best management approach for gastroschisis in a neonate?
questions.solution:
A neonate with gastroschisis would need an immediate primary closure. Primary closure under general anesthesia or gradual reduction using a preformed silo may be performed. Parenteral nutrition is often needed for several weeks to support intestinal recovery.  

Gastroschisis is an abdominal wall defect located on one side of the umbilicus (right side commonly) allowing protrusion of the intestines, stomach, bladder, and sometimes ovaries or undescended testes. The loops of the bowel are not covered by amnion as they herniate through the abdominal wall directly into the amniotic cavity. The affected bowel loops can be damaged by exposure to amniotic fluid.

Risk factors include teenage pregnancy, recreational drug use, smoking, and genitourinary infection during pregnancy. After birth, careful management is required to prevent twisting or kinking of the blood supply to the intestines. The abdomen is wrapped with transparent plastic wrap, a nasogastric tube is inserted, and fluid resuscitation is initiated.

Management: Immediate surgical intervention is required after birth to prevent complications such as infection, dehydration, and damage to the exposed abdominal organs. Surgical repair typically involves gently placing the protruding abdominal contents back into the abdominal cavity and closing the abdominal wall defect surgically. This approach helps protect the exposed organs, prevent complications, and facilitate normal abdominal wall development.

questions.text: The first step in the management of a hemodynamically stable patient with the following rhythm is_____________
questions.solution:
Intravenous Amiodarone is the first step in the management of a hemodynamically stable patient with a rhythm strip showing ventricular tachycardia. The above EKG shows rapid heart rate (>100 bpm), regular rhythm, wide complex QRS (>120 ms), all QRS complexes are similar (monomorphic). This EKG diagnostic of a sustained monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT).

Intravenous amiodarone is recommended by the AHA/ACC 2015 guidelines for the treatment of hemodynamically stable ventricular tachycardia.

Chest compressions are the first step in unresponsive patients without a pulse.

Synchronized cardioversion is the treatment of choice for hemodynamically unstable patients (hypotension, respiratory distress, altered sensorium) with ventricular tachycardia.

Carotid massage is contraindicated in ventricular tachycardia.

Note: IV Lidocaine / IV Procainamide can also be used if amiodarone is unavailable in the above scenario depicted in the question.

questions.text: As an epidemiologist, you are assigned to calculate the maternal mortality ratio in your area. Which of the following parameters will you not take into account while calculating this ratio?

choices.text: Maternal deaths due to road traffic accidents

questions.solution:
Total live births and deaths due peripartum infections and postpartum haemorrhage will be taken into account while calculating the maternal mortality ratio (MMR).

MMR = (Number of maternal deaths in a given year / Number of live births in the same area and year) x 1,00,000 (or 1000).

Maternal mortality refers to deaths during pregnancy or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, from causes related to pregnancy. 

Related Pearl: Maternal Mortality Ratio

Maternal death is defined as the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.

  • Maternal mortality ratio is the number of maternal deaths in a given period per 100,000 live births during the same period.
  • MMR = Number of maternal deaths in a period x 100,000 (or 1000)/Number of live births in the same period
  • Main global causes of maternal deaths are severe bleeding, indirect causes (anemia, malaria, heart diseases), infections, unsafe abortions, eclampsia, obstructed labor and other direct causes like ectopic pregnancy, anesthesia related complications, etc.
  • In India, the most common causes of maternal deaths are hemorrhage (leading cause), sepsis, obstructed labor, hypertensive disorders, etc.

questions.text: In a given population, 4050 births were recorded over a period of 1 year. Among these, 50 were stillbirths, 50 died in the 1st week of life and 150 died within 8-28 days of life. What is the neonatal mortality rate of this population?
questions.solution:
The neonatal mortality rate (NMR) of the given population is 50 per 1000 live births.

Neonatal mortality rate = No. of deaths of neonates < 28 days within a year x 1000 / Total live births in the same year

In this population, there were 4000 live births (no. of total births - no. of stillbirths).

NMR = (50+150) x 1000/4000 = 100/2 = 50

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery for breast carcinoma. She now presents with painless swelling involving the arm as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the image are suggestive of post-mastectomy lymphedema involving the upper limb.

Lymphoedema occurs when interstitial fluid accumulates due to defective lymphatic drainage. It is a common complication of breast cancer treatment involving axillary lymph node dissection and radiotherapy. Sentinel lymph node dissection (SLND) reduces the risk of lymphedema significantly.

Clinical signs and symptoms are observed in the ipsilateral arm. A significant increase in the limb size due to swelling is seen. Other symptoms are heaviness, tightness, numbness, tingling, limb fatigue, and reduced limb mobility.

Diagnosis is predominantly based on the clinical swelling of the arm. The girth of the affected arm >2 centimeters than the normal limb, a 200-mL or more increase in limb volume, or a 5% or greater limb volume change are other diagnostic criteria.

Management:

Limb elevation, elastic arm stockings, and pneumatic compression devices can help reduce swelling. 

Dry skin can be seen due to fluid accumulation, which can lead to cellulitis/skin infections. Using a low pH water-based moisturizer is helpful.

Manual lymphatic drainage (MLD) by a therapist followed by simple lymphatic drainage (SLD) by the patient daily aids interstitial fluid evacuation.

Benzpyrones and flavonoids are some naturally occurring substances that may be of use to treat lymphedema.

Surgical options are lymphaticovenular anastomosis, liposuction, and debulking.

Other options:

Option B:   Stewart-Treves syndrome refers to lymphangiosarcoma seen in chronic long-standing lymphedema following mastectomy (more than 10 years). They present as single/multiple bluish-red skin and subcutaneous nodules. They can ulcerate and hemorrhage.

Option C: Axillary venous thrombosis or Paget-Schrotter disease is seen in patients doing rigorous exercise and in weightlifters. The subclavian vein is compressed at the thoracic outlet. Painful swelling of the arm is observed.

Option D: Cellulitis usually presents with an ulcer and the skin is erythematous, swollen, and painful. Fever, chills, and rigor follow.

questions.text: A male patient, chronic smoker presented with cough and skin hyperpigmentation. During further evaluation, he is found to have high ACTH levels that remained high even after administration of high-dose dexamethasone. What is the underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Elevated ACTH levels that do not get suppressed by a high-dose dexamethasone test are suggestive of Cushing’s syndrome secondary to an ectopic ACTH-secreting tumor. Considering the patient's smoking status and cough it is likely to be a lung tumor.

Ectopic sources of ACTH include small cell lung cancers and pulmonary carcinoid tumors. The most effective treatment strategy is the management of the underlying SCLC or carcinoid.

Option B: Pituitary adenoma presents with elevated ACTH but a high-dose dexamethasone suppression test is positive (suppressed).

questions.text: A patient was undergoing the ERCP for the removal of gallstones. However, it required multiple attempts to retrieve the stone. What is the commonest complication expected in such cases after the procedure?
questions.solution:
Pancreatitis is the most common complication of ERCP. (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangio Pancreatography). The Pancreatitis is usually mild and resolves in a few days.

Multiple attempts at cannulation, sphincter of Oddi dysfunction or history of recurrent pancreatitis and therapeutic procedures instead of diagnostic ones impart a higher risk of pancreatitis

In this procedure, a side-viewing endoscope is passed through the pylorus of the stomach into the second part of the duodenum to visualize the papilla.

It is then cannulated, and dye is injected into the pancreatic or bile duct to visualize the pancreatic or biliary tree. Minor procedures like biopsy and endoscopic stone removal can be done via this itself.

questions.text: The triad of Situs inversus totalis, chronic sinusitis and bronchiectasis indicates the diagnosis of __________.
questions.solution:
This clinical triad is suggestive of Kartagener syndrome.

The primary defect in Kartagener’s Syndrome is primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD). Patients with PCD (also called immotile cilia syndrome) have Kartagener triad, characterized by:

  1. Situs inversus totalis
  2. Bronchiectasis
  3. Chronic sinusitis

Primary ciliary dyskinesia

  • Defects in ciliary motor proteins leads to ciliary dysfunction. This causes the retention of secretions due to a failed mucociliary clearance mechanism. Clinically, this manifests as chronic sinusitis and recurrent infections that ultimately lead to bronchiectasis.
  • Ciliary function is necessary during development to ensure proper rotation of the developing organs in the chest and abdomen. In its absence, their location becomes a matter of chance. As a result, approximately half of the patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia have Kartagener syndrome, marked by situs inversus or a partial lateralizing abnormality along with chronic sinusitis and bronchiectasis.
  • Males with this condition tend to be infertile, as a result of sperm dysmotility due to impaired sperm flagella function.

Other options:

  • Churg-Strauss syndrome - Consists of asthma, fever, eosinophilia, vasculitis and granuloma.
  • Cystic fibrosis -  It is a multisystem disorder caused by the dysfuction of cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator protein (CFTR). It is an autosomal recessive trait with multiple clinical manifestations involving GIT, respiratory tract, pancreas, genitourinary tract and sweat glands.
  • Young syndrome - It consists of sinopulmonary disease and azoospermia.

questions.text: A newborn presents with jaundice. Biliary atresia is suspected when jaundice is persistent and exceeds:
questions.solution:
Newborns with persistent jaundice for more than 2 weeks suggests a diagnosis of biliary atresia. 

Biliary atresia may also be termed as noncystic obliterative cholangiopathy. It is a disease of the intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts of unknown etiology. 

The classification of biliary atresia is as follows:

Type I - Common bile duct

Type II a - Common hepatic duct

Type II b - Common bile duct, hepatic duct, cystic duct.

Type III -Common bile duct, hepatic duct, cystic duct, no anastomosable ducts at porta hepatis 

Type III biliary atresia is the most common type. If the gall bladder and bile ducts are patent in type IIb, they can be used as a conduit. 

Clinical features include persistent jaundice, clay-colored stools, and hepatomegaly. Untreated newborns will show signs of liver cirrhosis and failure (ascites, portal hypertension, and failure to thrive). 

Laboratory evaluation will show elevated levels of direct and indirect bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase, and gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase. Ultrasound will show hypoplastic or absent gall bladder and triangular cord sign. 

Hepatobiliary scintigraphy can also be performed. 

Treatment is surgery via Kasai procedure or liver transplantation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida with a low-risk pregnancy presents at 39 weeks for a normal health check. Her vitals are stable. On PV, her cervix is 4 cm dilated. A repeat PV  after 4 hours shows that her cervix is 6 cm dilated. The fetal head is at +2 station and membranes are absent. Liquor is clear and uterine contractions are good. Fetal heart rate is 150 BPM and reassuring. What is the appropriate course of management?

choices.text: Rupture of membranes and confirm cord prolapse

questions.solution:
The appropriate course of management for this 28-year-old primigravida with the given clinical scenario is to wait and watch.

The patient is low-risk, stable, and in active labor with progressive cervical dilation from 4 cm to 6 cm in 4 hours. This indicates that labor is progressing adequately.

The fetal head is at +2 station, indicating descent into the birth canal, which is a positive sign of labor progression. The absence of membranes suggests that the patient has experienced spontaneous rupture of membranes (SROM), which is a normal occurrence during labor. Clear liquor and reassuring fetal heart rate (150 BPM) indicate fetal well-being.

If there are any signs of labor dystocia or fetal distress during monitoring, appropriate interventions can be considered at that time.

Other options:

  • Oxytocin augmentation or rupture of membranes without clear indications may lead to unnecessary interventions and potential complications.
  • Emergency Caesarean section is not warranted in the absence of fetal distress or other complications.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented to the casualty department with torticollis and dystonia. His attender reported that he had been diagnosed with schizophrenia and had recently started treatment with Haloperidol. What is the next best step to treat the patient's presenting symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient on haloperidol developed extra-pyramidal symptoms of torticollis and dystonia. The next best step in his management to alleviate his symptoms would be to administer benzhexol, an anticholinergic medication

Benzhexol, also known as trihexiphenidylis an antimuscarinic agent. Drug-induced parkinsonism is a condition that is caused by certain drugs that have D2 antagonistic action like typical antipsychotics. Due to the decrease in dopaminergic activity, they result in an unbalanced cholinergic activity. Benzhexol acts by restoring the balance of the cholinergics in the striatal interneurons.

questions.text: The below image is of a femur bone. Which of the following muscles is attached to "A"?
questions.solution:
The image shows the posterior surface of the right femur and the structure marked "A" is the lesser trochanter where the iliopsoas muscle is attached.

The Iliopsoas comprises of Psoas major and Iliacus. They arise from the lumbar spine and the inner surface of the ilium bone respectively, and insert on the lesser trochanter. The iliopsoas cause flexion of the hip.

The femur can be divided into the proximal femur, shaft, and distal femur.

  • The proximal femur consists of the head, neck, greater and lesser trochanters. The intertrochanteric line is present on the anterior surface at the junction of the neck and shaft of the femur while the intertrochanteric crest is present on the posterior surface. The lesser trochanter is the posteromedial projection of the femur arising posteroinferiorly from the neck-shaft junction.
  • The shaft of the femur consists of linea aspera (bony crest present on the posterior surface), gluteal tuberosity, and pectineal line.
  • The distal femur consists of the medial condyle, lateral condyle, intercondylar fossa, and patellar surface.

questions.text: A farmer is brought to the hospital following a snake bite on the right foot. Two fang marks were observed on the dorsum of the foot along with minimal pain, swelling and bleeding at the site. The vitals were stable. Which of the following is the immediate step of management?

choices.text: Use sling or splint for right lower limb (pressure)  immobilization
Look for dead snake brought by relatives

questions.solution:
The immediate management of snakebite will include immobilization using a sling or splint.

Immobilization is done to minimize the spread of the venom. Hospitalization, followed by ASV administration is the definitive management of snake bites.

Measures that can be done in the case of snakebite:

  • Apply firm pressure over the bitten area, which delays the absorption of venom
  • Pressure immobilization is recommended for elapid and sea-snake bites, but not for viper bites as it may cause local necrosis
  • Clean the wound with soap and water, or iodine and cover it with a sterile dressing 
  • Immediately apply a broad firm bandage (Sutherland wrap) on the bitten area and around the limb. As much of the limb should be bandaged as possible. It should be tight enough to occlude the superficial venous and lymphatic return, but not the arterial or deep venous flow. 
  • In bites on the trunk, head, or neck, apply firm pressure over the bitten area
  • Immobilize the limb, as movement can accelerate the spread of venom
  • Make the patient lie on one side in the recovery position so that the airway is clear, in case of vomiting or fainting

Measures contraindicated in the case of snakebite:

  • Suction and incision of the wound
  • Electric shock treatment of wound site
  • Application of tourniquets because they obstruct arterial flow and cause ischemia
  • Ice water immersion of the bitten limb

questions.text: A male patient who is HIV-positive, presents with persistent headaches, confusion, and fever. Further cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis revealed a positive India ink stain. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The image clinical scenario indicates meningitis caused by the fungus cryptococcus.

Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungus that is found worldwide as a saprophyte in soil enriched with pigeon droppings. It may cause infection in immune-competent people, resulting in a flu-like illness with complete recovery.

Infection in immunocompromised people like AIDS patients or patients with hematological malignancies results in meningoencephalitis.

The image below shows India ink preparation which is employed to detect the presence of capsulated yeast, cryptococcus neoformans. It induces negative staining by creating a black, semi-opaque background that makes the capsule of the yeast clearly visible. Cryptococcus has a polysaccharide capsule which is demonstrated as clear halos against a black background.

Mucicarmine stain can also be used in the identification of cryptococcus. The image given below shows mucicarmine stained specimen of lung tissue containing cryptococci.

Culture on Sabouraud dextrose agar (SDA) at 37'C appears as smooth, mucoid, and creamy white. The cryptococcal antigen(in serum and CSF) is sensitive and specific and can be demonstrated by the latex agglutination test.

Treatment of cryptococcal meningitis involves a combination therapy of amphotericin B with flucytosine. Fluconazole can be added with these drugs in AIDS patients to prevent relapse.

questions.text: Inguinal bubo is caused by which of the microorganisms?
questions.solution:
The presence of inguinal bubo is a characteristic feature of chancroid, which is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi.

Inguinal bubo refers to swollen and tender lymph nodes (lymphadenopathy) in the inguinal (groin) region, which is a common presentation of chancroid due to regional lymph node involvement.

Other Options: 

Diphtheria, caused by Corynebacterium diphtheria causes and the typical lesion early in the disease is a superficial ulcer, oval, rounded, or irregularly linear in shape with a clearly defined, overhanging edge. The ulcer may later become deeper and the edge becomes rolled, raised, and avascular. It is usually seen around the umbilicus, behind the ears, genito-crural flexure, or in the clefts.

Donovanosis, Klebsiella granulomatis previously known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis causes a sexually transmitted disease. The incubation period is 1–12 weeks. It presents as a painless beefy red ulcer that bleeds readily on touch. Lymph node involvement is rare. However, pseudo buboes (subcutaneous granulomas) may be seen in the inguinal region in 10% of cases due to subcutaneous abscess.

Gonorrhea is caused by the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae and can lead to various symptoms, including genital discharge and inflammation. While gonorrhea can involve the inguinal lymph nodes, it is not typically associated with the term "inguinal bubo." The major symptoms include urethritis, vaginal discharge, dyspareunia, and dysuria.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient presented with painless, fleshy, exophytic lesions on the surface of the genitalia. She is 14-weeks pregnant. It is found to be caused by low-risk strains of HPV. Which of the following is the safest and can be used to manage this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of painless exophytic lesions on the genitalia and caused by low-risk HPV strains is suggestive of Anogenital warts. Cryotherapy is the safest management that can be used in pregnant women for treating warts.

Anogenital warts is a genital infection caused by the human papillomavirus(HPV) commonly HPV‐6 and HPV‐11. Transmission of HPV commonly occurs sexually or through the genital lesions of the mother during delivery. Giant warts are called Condyloma acuminata.

The lesions present as soft, pink and flesy warts. These growths may be pedunculated discrete or verrucous and coalesce to form large cauliflower-like growths. It commonly occurs on the glans, corona, and frenulum in men and the posterior fourchette in women. Diagnosis is done by HPV DNA PCR (polymerase chain reaction). 

Management (non-pregnant):

The first-line drugs used in the treatment are podophyllin and imiquimod. Podophyllin is the most commonly used drug for anogenital warts and is used as a local application of podophyllin 25% in alcohol or podophyllin 20% in tincture benzoin or podophyllin cream. Imiquimod is also used as a first-line drug next to podophyllin and is used as a 5% cream applied 3 times per week.

Second-line management includes Cryotherapy, Surgical removal of warts, laser and 80-90% trichloroacetic acid. Fluorouracil 5% and 25% trichloroacetic acid combination causes small warts to fall off by 3-4 days and is also used as a second-line management. Cryotherapy is the safest management that can be used in pregnant women for treating warts.

As imiquimod, podophyllin, and podofilox should not be used during pregnancy, cryotherapy is considered relatively safer.

Interferon therapy can be used for severe extensive warts.

Cryotherapy:

This treatment is physician administered. Dimethyl ether spray, carbon dioxide snow and liquid nitrogen all produce cold thermal damage to the skin.

Liquid nitrogen produces the coldest freeze and is commonly used in practice. It is applied using a cotton wool bud or a cryospray until a rim of iced tissue (seen as a white discoloration) develops around the wart. The freeze is maintained for 5–30 sec depending on the size and site of the wart. Scarring is unlikely with freezing times under 30 secs.

questions.text: A 20-year-old survivor of a terrorist attack that happened 2 weeks ago comes to the psychiatry OPD with complaints of persistent flashbacks about the incident. She has been unable to sleep properly and is avoiding going to crowded places. She is no longer interested in doing activities with her friends. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is acute stress disorder, because the symptoms have been present for less than one month.

Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and acute stress disorder both present with the same set of symptoms:

  • Intrusive symptoms such as recurrent nightmares and flashbacks of the event, psychological distress due to stimuli that are reminders of prior trauma
  • Avoidance of external reminders of trauma
  • Negative mood or cognition related to the trauma, such as diminished interest in activities and withdrawal
  • Altered level of arousal, such as sleep disturbances and hypervigilance

A diagnosis of PTSD is made if these symptoms present ≥1 month following the traumatic event. If these symptoms are present prior to 1 month, then a diagnosis of acute stress disorder is made.

The treatment modalities for PTSD and acute stress disorder include trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy, eye movement desensitization and reprocessing therapy (EMDR), and SSRIs. 

Adjustment disorder (option B) is diagnosed when the patient has emotional or behavioral changes following a stressor in his life. However, the distress is out of proportion to the stressor itself — that is, the feeling of distress is subjective.

Major depressive disorder (option C) presents with low mood, loss of interest in pleasurable activities, and decreased energy. Although this patient has a loss of interest in activities, the presence of hypervigilance symptoms and flashbacks following a traumatic event points towards a diagnosis of a stress-trauma related disorder.

questions.text: A patient is brought in to the casualty with maxillofacial trauma after an RTA. He is unconscious with a dropping SpO2. The ER doctor decides to intubate him. What is the preferred method of intubation for this patient?
questions.solution:
Patients with severe maxillofacial trauma are very likely to experience severe airway compromise or obstruction. Hence to maintain airway competency, intubation is necessary and in the above case, the presence of facial trauma, tracheostomy is ideal.

Tracheostomy involves making an opening and placing a stoma in the anterior wall of the trachea. 

Functions: 

  1. Provides an alternative pathway for breathing by bypassing the obstruction.
  2. Improves alveolar ventilation by reducing dead space by 30-50% and reducing airway resistance
  3. Uses a cuff to protect the airways from secretions and blood
  4. Allows suction of secretions in the setting of the impaired cough reflex.
  5. Allows positive pressure respiration
  6. Allows administration of anesthesia

Indications: 

  1. Respiratory obstruction due to 
    1. Infections (laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis, epiglottitis, diphtheria)
    2. Trauma due to external injury, mandibular or maxillofacial fractures
    3. Neoplasms
    4. Foreign bodies or edema
    5. Bilateral abductor paralysis
    6. Congenital anomalies
  2. Retained secretions
    1. Inability to cough due to coma, spasm, or paralysis of respiratory muscles
    2. Aspiration of pharyngeal secretions
    3. Painful cough
  3. Respiratory insufficiency due to emphysema, chronic bronchitis

Other options:

Option A and B: Mask ventilation and LMA are not enough as the patient has severe airway compromise.

Option D:  Nasotracheal intubation is contraindicated in the presence of facial trauma because if there is an undiscovered fracture at the base of the skull, the tube could be forced through it and into the brain.

questions.text: A patient stopped alcohol consumption for 3 days and presented with irritability, disorientation, paranoid delusions, agitation, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient who has not consumed alcohol for the past 3 days with disorientation, paranoid delusions, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium is suggestive of delirium tremens.

Delirium tremens is a medical emergency that occurs during alcohol withdrawal. It is an acute condition and usually develops within 72 hours after the last drink. It has symptoms of both delirium and alcohol withdrawal. The clinical features of delirium tremens are:

  • Altered sensorium with disorientation
  • Perceptual distortions, most frequently tactile or visual hallucinations
  • Autonomic hyperactivity with tachycardia, fever, anxiety, insomnia, hypertension. And sweating
  • Fluctuating levels of psychomotor activity, ranging from agitation to lethargy
  • Altered sleep-wake cycle

Other options:

Option B - Wernicke’s encephalopathy (alcoholic encephalopathy) is associated with thiamine deficiency. Alcohol abuse may lead to thiamine deficiency because of poor nutritional habits, or malabsorption. It is an acute neurological disorder characterized by:

  • Global confusion
  • Ocular abnormalities like horizontal nystagmus, gaze palsy, anisocoria, and sluggish pupillary reflex
  • Ataxia - mainly affecting the gait
  • Vestibular dysfunction

It may resolve with thiamine therapy or progress to Korsakoff's syndrome.

Option C - Korsakoff’s psychosis can follow Wernicke’s encephalopathy due to thiamine deficiency. It is a chronic amnestic syndrome that is characterized by the following clinical symptoms in an intact and responsive patient:

  • Impaired mental syndrome, especially recent memory
  • Anterograde amnesia
  • Confabulation

Option D - Alcohol-induced psychosis is characterized by the development of auditory hallucinations or paranoid delusions in the context of a heavy drinking or alcohol withdrawal. These patients have a clear sensorium, unlike the patients having delirium tremens.

Note: Tremulousness is the first alcohol withdrawal symptom.

questions.text: A 3-year child is brought to the pediatrician for the evaluation of the lateral neck mass. On examination, a painless, soft, fluctuating mass is found in the lateral side of the neck as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A soft, painless, fluctuating mass found in the posterior part of the neck in a child, is most likely to be a cystic hygroma.

Cystic hygroma is a lymph filled sac that results from the obstruction of the lymph vessels during their development. It is most commonly present in the posterior triangle of the neck. The mass may be apparent at birth or may appear in early childhood due to the increased accumulation of lymph. Since the sac is filled with lymph, it is soft, fluctuating, and brilliantly transilluminant.

Treatment:

  • Lymphangiomas are treated by surgical excision and image-guided sclerotherapy.
  • Initially, surgical excision is done to safely remove the lymphatic malformation without causing any damage to the adjacent vital tissues such as blood vessels, nerves, or muscles.
  • For large tumors and the tumors that extend to the base of the tongue or floor of the mouth, combined sclerotherapy and surgical resection are done.
  • If there is any residual lymphatic malformation after the treatment, then a conservative excision or unroofing of the cyst is done. It may be combined with sclerosing therapy or repeated partial excisions.

Note: The terms lymphangioma and cystic hygromas are older terms. They are now called lymphatic malformations.

Option B: A thyroglossal duct cyst is a congenital midline neck swelling that typically presents during childhood often noticed after an upper respiratory infection. Classically the cyst moves upwards on swallowing and on tongue protrusion. This indicates attachment to the hyoid bone and the swelling is smooth, soft, fluctuant (cystic), non-tender, mobile, and shows transillumination.

Option C : Ranula is a transilluminant mucocele. It is also known as "frog's belly", as it resembles the vocal sacs of a frog. It occurs due to an obstruction in the sublingual salivary gland. A ranula usually presents as a large, tense, bluish swelling on the floor of the mouth to one side on the midline. If the obstruction happens in the ducts of minor salivary glands such as labial or buccal, it is termed mucocele.

Option D: Cervical lymphadenopathy is seen in children with infections of the parotid and upper respiratory tract infections. On palpation, they are firm and non-fluctuant.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient presented with purplish, itchy, flat-topped lesions on his shins for the past 3 months. The patient also gives a history of chewing tobacco for 20 years. She occasionally drinks alcohol and smokes. On examination, the lesions are seen as in the image below. Which of the following is the first line of management?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and characteristic lesions showing fine white lacework in buccal mucosa called Wickham's striae shown in the image are diagnostic of lichen planus. The first line of management is potent topical corticosteroids like clobetasol propionate ointment 0.05%.

Lichen planus is a type of lichenoid disorder affecting the papillary dermis. It is a T-cell mediated autoimmune disease against the basal keratinocytes. Various factors that can precipitate the disease are:

  • Viruses like Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C, Human herpesviruses (HHV-6, HHV-8), Varicella zoster
  • Betel quid which contains areca nut and tobacco leaf
  • Environmental factors like:
    • Drugs like antimicrobials, antihypertensives, antimalarials, antidepressants, anticonvulsants
    • Radiotherapy
    • Anxiety, depression, stress

It is recommended to avoid spicy and acidic foods, as well as avoid tobacco and alcohol.

The most common presentation of lichen planus is a well-defined area of purple-colored, itchy, flat-topped papules. This description is known as the characteristic "6 Ps" of lichen planus: planar (flat-topped), purple, polygonal, pruritic, papules, and plaques.

White streaks forming a lacework in buccal mucosa are characteristic features and are known as Wickham’s striae.

Histology: Most useful investigation to confirm the diagnosis. Basal epidermal cell degeneration/destruction by dermal CD8+ T lymphocytes is characteristically seen in lichen planus. Other findings are:

  • Hyperkeratosis
  • The degeneration leads to the formation of spaces in the epidermis known as Max-Joseph spaces.
  • Saw-toothed appearance of the Rete ridges
  • Band-like lymphocytic infiltrate is present at the dermo-epidermal junction. 

Other options:

Options A and C: Ciclosporin, and methotrexate are used in third-line management and not first-line management of the disease.

Option D: Oral corticosteroids are used in the second-line management of the disease.

questions.text: A child was brought in the ER with a head injury. He also had a seizure on the way to the hospital. What is the likely percentage of early seizures in such patients?
questions.solution:
Early seizures are a common complication of head injuries, occurring in approximately 2% to 17% of all patients with such injuries. Children are more likely to experience early seizures than adults, and the frequency of seizures correlates with the severity of the head injury.

For instance, severe head injuries often lead to a higher frequency of early seizures, with rates ranging from 10% to 15% for adults and 30% to 35% for children.

A significant portion of early seizures, approximately 50%, occur within the first 24 hours following the head trauma. Additionally, within the first 4 weeks post-injury, about 10% of seizures happen within the initial week.

Given these statistics, the prevalence of early seizures after head injuries can reach up to 17%, indicating the importance of vigilance and appropriate management strategies in patients with head trauma.

questions.text: During a police investigation, the police found some bones in the open space. Which of the following tests can be used to differentiate between human and animal bones?
questions.solution:
The test used to differentiate human bones from animal bones is the precipitin test. 

The origin of skin, flesh, bone, blood, or even secretions, such as saliva, milk, and semen, is determined by this test. Precipitin test is used for species identification of semen, blood, or saliva, and a positive test confirms human origin. The precipitin test identifies the presence of proteins that are found only in human blood.

Other options: 

Teichmann test and Takayama test (Options A and D) are used to confirm the presence of blood but cannot be used for species identification of blood.

Barberio test (Option C) is used for the detection of spermatic fluid. 

Related Pearl: Tests to detect seminal and blood stains

Tests for seminal stains

  • Barberio's test
  • Florence test
  • Acid phosphatase test
  • Creatine phosphokinase test
  • Immunological test to detect Prostate Specific Antigen

Tests for blood stains  

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text: A 56-year-old multiparous woman presented with grade II/III uterine prolapse with cystocele. She complains of passing urine on coughing and sneezing. What is the type of urinary incontinence seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The type of urinary incontinence present in a patient with prolapse and cystocele experiencing urination on coughing and sneezing is stress incontinence.

Stress incontinence refers to the involuntary leakage of urine when there is increased intraabdominal pressure (eg, coughing, sneezing, laughing, Valsalva manoeuvre). There is an absence of detrusor muscle contraction, seen in urodynamic studies.

Causes:

  • Age and menopause - due to estrogen deficiency
  • Multiparity - due to loss of pelvic muscle tone
  • Obesity
  • Smoking
  • Constipation, chronic cough
  • Pelvic organ prolapse
  • Pregnancy - due to the effect of progesterone and pressure of the gravid uterus on the bladder neck.
  • Puerperium - due to descent of the bladder neck, loss of urethro-vesical angle, and reduced pelvic muscle tone 
  • Surgical repair of vesicovaginal fistula

Grading of genuine stress incontinence (GSI) :

  • Grade I: Incontinence with only severe stress, such as coughing, sneezing, and jogging.
  • Grade II: Incontinence with moderate stress, such as fast walking, and going up and down the stairs.
  • Grade III: Incontinence with mild stress such as standing.

Investigations are only done before surgery to confirm the diagnosis. They include the stress test, cotton swab or Q tip test, Marshall and Bonney’s test, urethroscopy, and urodynamic studies. These are not required before conservative management.

Conservative management includes Kegel's pelvic exercises, electric nerve stimulation, devices like pessaries, vaginal cones, and artificial sphincters. Medical treatment with estrogen creams, anti-adrenergic, venlafaxine, and imipramine may be useful.

Other options:

Option A: Overflow incontinence is an old term that refers to the inability to empty the bladder, with involuntary, continuous urinary dribbling. Currently, it refers to another presentation of urge incontinence. 

Option B: Urge incontinence is the involuntary escape of urine when there is an imminent need to urinate. It occurs due to detrusor muscle overactivity or detrusor instability. It is seen more commonly in old women with decreased bladder capacity, decreased sensation, and central nervous system (CNS) inhibition. 

Option D: Neurogenic bladder occurs in patients with neurogenic dysfunction leading to detrusor hyperreflexia. Conditions such as multiple sclerosis, stroke, Parkinson's disease, and spinal injury give rise to this. They present with urgency or urge incontinence.

questions.text: The empty delta sign is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The empty delta sign is a CT sign of cerebral venous thrombosis.

The 'empty delta' sign is a CT sign of dural venous sinus thrombosis of the superior sagittal sinus, where the thrombus becomes less dense and the contrast outlines a triangular filling defect (clot) within the sinus lumen. It is only described with contrast-enhanced CT-scan (CECT) or MRI with contrast (not with non-contrast CT(NCCT) or non-contrast MRI).

On doing an NCCT scan, an acutely thrombosed sinus appears hyperdense and expanded. This is called the 'delta sign'. 

 

Related Pearl: Intracranial haemorrhages

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient presented to surgery OPD with a history of intermittent purulent discharge with a slight blood tinge from an external opening located in the perianal region even after multiple drainage attempts.Examination of the perianal region is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of fistula-in-ano. Laying open fistulotomy is the surest management method to eradicate the disease. 

Fistula-in -ano:

A fistula-in-ano is an abnormal hollow tract or cavity that is lined with granulation tissue and that connects a primary opening inside the anal canal to a secondary opening in the perianal skin.

The most common cause is perianal abscess. Other causes include tuberculosis or Crohn's disease.

Symptoms:

  • Perianal pain
  • Discharge - intermittent purulent discharge (which may be bloody) 

Goodsall's rule:

Goodsall’s rule can be used as a guide in determining the location of the internal opening of the fistula.

  • Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening by a short, radial tract.
  • Fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline.

Exceptions to Goodsall’s Rule

However, exceptions to this rule often occur: Fistulas with an anterior external opening greater than 3 cm from the anal margin usually track to the posterior midline.

Investigations:

The investigations available for fistula-in-ano are as follows:

  • Fistulogram
  • Endoanal ultrasound
  • MRI
  • Computed tomography (CT) scan
  • Endocoil MRI
  • Hydrogen peroxide–enhanced 3-D endoanal ultrasonography

Fistula-in-ano is surgically managed by fistulotomy, fistulectomy, ligation of the inter-sphincteric fistula tract (LIFT), or setons

questions.text: Identify the correct anatomies from the CT scan given below:

choices.text: A- Kidney, B- Liver, C- Pancreas
A- Liver, B- Pancreas, C- Spleen
A- Spleen, B- Kidney, C- Liver
A- Pancreas, B- Liver, C- Spleen

questions.solution:
The correct identification of structures marked as A, B, and C in the CT image is: A-Liver, B-Pancreas, C-Spleen.

A - Liver: The liver is an organ located in the upper right portion of the abdomen. On a CT scan, the liver has a homogeneous appearance with well-defined borders. The liver's density is higher compared to surrounding organs due to its composition of hepatocytes and blood vessels. Additionally, blood vessels such as the hepatic artery and portal vein can be seen supplying blood to the liver. 

B - Pancreas: The pancreas is a glandular organ situated behind the stomach and adjacent to the first part of the small intestine (duodenum). On a CT scan, the pancreas appears as a soft tissue structure with a slightly lower density compared to the liver. It typically has a lobulated appearance and is located in the retroperitoneal space. The pancreatic duct may also be visualized, extending from the pancreas to the duodenum. 

C - Spleen: The spleen is an organ located in the upper left portion of the abdomen, beneath the diaphragm and behind the stomach. On a CT scan, the spleen appears as a well-defined structure with a homogeneous density similar to the liver. It typically has a slightly lower density compared to the liver.

questions.text: X-ray of a patient appears as below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the provided X-ray image, there is evidence of complete opacification (whitening) of the left lung field, along with a shift of the mediastinum (central structure in the chest containing the heart and major blood vessels) towards the affected side. These findings are indicative of a lung collapse, also known as atelectasis.

Other Options:

Option A: Pneumonia may present with airspace opacification in the lungs, but it usually does not result in complete opacification of an entire lung field as seen in the provided image.

Option B: Pleural effusion typically appears as a blunting of the costophrenic angles or as increased opacity at the lung bases on a chest X-ray.

Option D: Hydropneumothorax refers to the presence of both fluid (hydrop) and air (pneumo) in the pleural space. While it can cause lung collapse, it typically presents with a combination of radiographic findings indicating both air and fluid in the pleural space, such as an air-fluid level or a meniscus sign.

questions.text: The finding of the immunohistochemistry studies of a patient with a neurodegenerative disease is given below. Identify the structure marked in the image.
questions.solution:
The given image is the histological sample of the substantia nigra showing neurons with a Lewy body, extracellular neuromelanin, and pigment-laden macrophages in Parkinson's disease. 

Lewy bodies are single or multiple intracytoplasmic, round to elongated, eosinophilic inclusions that often have a dense core surrounded by a pale halo. Accumulations of these are seen in subcortical regions (basal ganglia, striatum, locus coeruleus, substantia nigra, thalamus) as well as the cerebral cortex.

Lewy bodies are aggregates of insoluble fibrillar proteins called alpha-synuclein (specific) and ubiquitin in the neural cells. They are typically seen in Parkinson's disease, Lewy body dementia, and a few variants of Alzheimer's disease. They mainly disrupt the excitatory dopaminergic pathways.

Other options:

Option A: Pick bodies are cytoplasmic, round to oval, weakly basophilic filamentous inclusions that stain strongly with silver methods. It contains 3R tau and is seen in frontotemporal lobar degeneration.

Option B: Negri bodies are cytoplasmic, round to oval, eosinophilic inclusions found in pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum. They are pathognomonic microscopic findings seen in rabies.

Option D: Lafora bodies are seen in the cytoplasm of neurons in myoclonic epilepsy. Lafora bodies are aggregates of polyglucosans, poorly constructed glycogen molecules with inordinately long strands that render them insoluble.

questions.text: A patient presents to the outpatient department (OPD) with wheezing and shortness of breath. On examination she is found to have low forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) and low FEV1 : FVC ratio. Patients with which of the following other conditions present similarly?
questions.solution:
The condition that shares a similar presentation with wheezing, shortness of breath, and low FEV1 is Asthma. Asthma is characterized by reversible airflow obstruction and commonly presents with wheezing, making it the most appropriate option among the choices provided.

Asthma is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the airways characterized by variable airflow obstruction, bronchial hyperresponsiveness, and respiratory symptoms such as wheezing, shortness of breath, cough, and chest tightness. Low FEV1 is commonly observed during asthma exacerbations due to airflow limitation and bronchoconstriction. Wheezing is a classic symptom of asthma, and reduced FEV1 reflects airflow obstruction.

Low FEV1 and FVC with a low FEV1/FVC ratio are characteristics for obstructive lung disease (OLD). 

Low FEV1 and FVC with a normal or high FEV1/FVC ratio are characteristics for restrictive lung disease (RLD). 

  • Obstructive lung diseases (OLD)
    • Asthma
    • COPD
    • Bronchiectasis
    • Bronchiolitis
  • Restrictive lung diseases (RLD)
    • Intrinsic
      • Interstitial lung disease
    • Extrinsic
      • Myasthenia gravis
      • Kyphoscoliosis
      • Pleural effusion

Other options:

A: Silicosis is a type of pneumoconiosis caused by inhalation of silica dust. It typically presents with symptoms such as cough, shortness of breath, and chest pain. However, wheezing and low FEV1 are not typical features of silicosis. Instead, silicosis is characterized by restrictive lung function abnormalities on pulmonary function tests.

B: Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF) is a progressive fibrotic lung disease characterized by scarring of the lung tissue. Common symptoms include progressive dyspnea (shortness of breath) and cough. While IPF can lead to reduced lung function and impaired gas exchange, wheezing is not a typical feature. Moreover, the pattern of lung function abnormalities in IPF typically demonstrates a restrictive pattern rather than airflow obstruction seen in asthma.

D: Interstitial Lung Disease (ILD) refers to a group of lung disorders characterized by inflammation and scarring (fibrosis) of the interstitium, the tissue that supports the air sacs of the lungs. ILD can present with symptoms such as dyspnea, cough, and crackles on auscultation. While ILD can lead to reduced lung volumes and impaired gas exchange, wheezing is not a typical feature. Additionally, ILD usually demonstrates a restrictive pattern on pulmonary function tests.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female undergoes emergency laparotomy. Which of the following is the surest sign of wound dehiscence?
questions.solution:
The surest sign of wound dehiscence is copious serosanguinous discharge.

Burst abdomen/Acute wound dehiscence is the mechanical wound failure causing separation of the closed abdominal wound associated with abdominal content evisceration. It usually occurs between the 5th and 8th postoperative days.

A sudden giving way feeling from the wound precipitated by bouts of cough, and pinkish serosanguinous discharge can be seen. Omentum or coils of the intestine are forced out of the wound.

Management includes delayed closure with initial mesh wrap or Bogota bag, placing a subcutaneous drain, suitable antibiotic therapy, and prevention of abdominal compartment syndrome as described above.

Below is an image showing a burst abdomen.

questions.text: What is the correct order of the normal phases of wound healing?

choices.text: Proliferative phase > Hemostatic phase > Inflammatory phase > Remodeling phase
Hemostatic phase > Inflammatory phase > Proliferative phase > Remodeling phase
Inflammatory phase > Hemostatic phase > Proliferative phase > Remodeling phase
Remodeling phase > Proliferative phase > Destructive phase > Inflammatory phase

questions.solution:
The correct order of the normal phases of wound healing is as follows: Hemostatic phase > Inflammatory phase > Proliferative phase > Remodeling phase.

Inflammatory phase: begins immediately after wounding and lasts 2-3 days. Bleeding is followed by vasoconstriction and thrombus formation to limit blood loss. Occasionally, the early part of inflammatory phase is called hemostatic phase.

Proliferative phase lasts from 3rd day to 3rd week consisting mainly of fibroblast activity with production of collagen and ground substance, growth of new blood vessels and re-epithelialization of the wound surface.

Remodeling phase is characterized by maturation of collagen- type 1 replacing type 3 until a ratio of 4:1 is achieved. The mature collagen leads to increased tensile strength and represents approximately 80% of the uninjured skin strength.

questions.text: Epidural anesthesia involves local anesthetic administration between
questions.solution:
Epidural anesthesia involves local anesthetic administration between the dura and ligamentum flavum.

Subdural injection (seen in a failed spinal anesthesia) is between dura and arachnoid.

Spinal anesthesia (subarachnoid block, intrathecal block) involves local anesthetic administration between the pia and arachnoid mater.

In spinal anesthesia, the local anesthetic is injected into CSF, which bathes the nerve root. Hence, a relatively small dose and volume of local anesthetic is sufficient to achieve dense sensory and motor blockade.

questions.text: During an autopsy, what is commonly used to preserve blood?
questions.solution:
10 mg/ml of sodium or potassium fluoride and potassium oxalate (anti-coagulant) is used to preserve blood.

Other preservatives used in toxicology postmortem include:

  • Saturated NaCl solution: Avoided in poisoning from corrosive acids, alkalis, corrosive sublimate, and aconite.
  • Fluoride should be added to urine, CSF, and vitreous humor if alcohol estimation is required and if analysis for cocaine, cyanide, and CO is being done.

A preservative is not necessary if :

  • The viscera can be analyzed in 24 hours
  • If the sample can be stored in a refrigerator or icebox
  • Bone, hair, nails specimens
  • Lung for inhaled poisons
  • The viscera should not be preserved in formaldehyde because extraction of non-volatile poisons becomes difficult.

In cases of chronic poisoning with heavy metals such as lead, arsenic, mercury, antimony, copper, etc., the shaft of a long bone, strands of scalp hair, fingernails or toenails, and a wedge of the quadriceps muscle should also be taken for sampling.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with gynecomastia. Ultrasonography (USG) reveals a 1-cm solid mass within the body of the testis. His serum testosterone is 600 ng/dL and estradiol is 35 pg/mL. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A 40-year-old man presenting with gynecomastia, testicular mass, and increased sex hormones is most likely to have  Leydig cell tumor of the testis.

Leydig cell tumor:

  • It is the most common sex-cord stromal type of testicular neoplasm.
  • It is mostly benign and invariably unilateral.
  • Most cases occur between 20 and 60 years of age; however, it can present at any age.
  • The most common presenting feature is testicular swelling or gynecomastia (~15% of cases).
  • In children, hormonal effects manifested primarily as sexual precocity, are the dominant features.
  • Tumors of Leydig cells may secrete androgens and estrogens, and even corticosteroids.

Grossly: Golden brown, homogeneous circumscribed nodules <5 cm in diameter.

Histologically:

  • large, round, or polygonal cells
  • round central nucleus and prominent nucleoli
  • abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm containing lipid droplets, vacuoles, or lipofuscin pigment
  • crystalloids of Reinke, rod-shaped eosinophilic cytoplasmic bodies are seen in about 25% of the tumors

Other options:

  • Sertoli cell tumor mostly presents as a painless testicular mass. They are usually hormonally silent but sometimes produces estrogen. In this patient, increased testosterone along with gynaecomastia make Leydig cell more likley.
  • Spermatocytic tumor mainly occurs in older adults as a slow-growing testicular mass. They do not secrete any hormones.
  • Granulosa cell tumor usually presents as a slow-growing and non-functioning testicular mass. Gynecomastia is rare.

questions.text: The finger-nose test is done to check the integrity of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The finger-nose test is done to assess cerebellar function.

Coordination in the upper limb is tested by finger-nose test. The patient is asked to touch his nose with the index finger of one hand. Then he is asked to touch the examiner's index finger. He is asked to do this multiple times, while the examiner keeps moving his index finger from place to place. It is important to ensure that the patient has to stretch his upper limb to reach the examiner's finger, so that the coordination can be assessed over the full range of motion of the upper limb.

Lower limb coordination is tested by heel-shin test. The test is done with the patient lying down on a bed. They are asked to put the heel of one leg onto the shin of the other leg, just below the knee. They are then asked to run the heel down the front of the shin till the dorsum of the foot. Patients with cerebellar lesions will have a tremor when trying to place the heel on the shin, and will be unable to accurately run the heel down the entire length of the shin.

The functioning of the posterior column tracts (option B) is assessed by Romberg's test. While performing Romberg's test, the patient is asked to stand with his feet close together, initially with his eyes open. If the patient is able to maintain their balance with the eyes open, they are asked to close their eyes. If they lose their balance and sway or fall with their eyes closed, the test is said to be positive. The examiner needs to be prepared to support the patient in case they are about to fall. 

Patients with disorders of the posterior column tracts will have impaired proprioception, and will have a positive Romberg's test. If the patient has dizziness or a tendency to fall even with the eyes open, then the lesion is likely to be in the vestibular system or cerebellum, and other relevant tests should be performed.

questions.text: A patient is suspected to have MEN-1 syndrome. Which of the following is the most common gastro-entero-pancreatic tumor seen in this syndrome?
questions.solution:
MEN 1 syndrome is characterized by the triad of tumors involving the parathyroids, pancreatic islets, and anterior pituitary. Gastrinoma is the most common gastro-entero-pancreatic tumor in MEN 1 syndrome.

Most common site of gastrinoma in MEN 1 syndrome is the first and second part of duodenum.

Gastrinoma if associated with marked gastric acid production and recurrent peptic ulcer is called Zollinger Ellison syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following inhalational agents has the blood-gas partition coefficient similar to Nitrous oxide?
questions.solution:
Desflurane is the inhalational anesthetic agent with the blood-gas partition coefficient similar to Nitrous oxide. 

Among the commonly used inhalational anesthetics, desflurane is the least fat-soluble which leads to a faster recovery. Desflurane is also minimally metabolized by the liver, thereby reducing hepatotoxicity. 

Inhalational agent Blood-gas partition coefficient
Halothane 2.5
Isoflurane 1.4
Sevoflurane 0.65
Desflurane 0.45
Nitrous oxide 0.4

Blood-gas partition co-efficient determines the solubility of the anesthetic agent in the blood. The higher the blood-gas partition coefficient, the higher will be the solubility of the anesthetic agent. This leads to its greater uptake by pulmonary circulation. The higher the uptake of the anesthetic agent, the higher the difference between the inspired and alveolar concentrations, which leads to a slower rate of induction and recovery. Desflurane has a very low blood:gas partition coefficient (0.42). Thus, the alveolar and blood concentrations rapidly rise to the level of inspired concentration, providing rapid induction of anesthesia and rapid recovery.

Other options:

Option A- Halothane is a high fat-soluble agent and can result in halothane hepatitis due to increased metabolism in obese individuals. Hence it is avoided.

Option C- Sevoflurane has a relatively higher fat solubility compared to desflurane.

Option D- Isoflurane has a higher fat-gas partition co-efficient resulting in increased recovery time from anesthesia.

questions.text: The maternal component of placenta would be
questions.solution:
The decidua basalis, also known as the basal plate, is the portion of the endometrium (uterine lining) that lies beneath the conceptus (embryo/fetus) and contributes to the formation of the maternal component of the placenta. It forms the maternal part of the placenta by coming into direct contact with the chorionic villi, allowing for the exchange of nutrients, gases, and waste products between the maternal and fetal circulations.

The definitive placenta (see image) consists of the chorionic plate on the fetal aspect and a basal plate on the maternal aspect with the intervillous space between them. The structures in each of these parts are as follows: 

Fetal side: Chorionic plate 

  • Amnion
  • Primary (extraembryonic) mesoderm with fetal blood vessels
  • Cytotrophoblast (Langhan's layer) 
  • Syncytiotrophoblast

Maternal side: Basal plate 

  • Stratum spongiosum of decidua basalis containing maternal blood vessels
  • Outer layer of syncytiotrophoblast (Nitabuch’s layer)
  • Outer shell of cytotrophoblast
  • Inner layer of syncytiotrophoblast (Rohr’s fibrinoid stria)

Between basal plate and chorionic plate

  • Intervillous space
  • Maternal blood flowing in the intervillous space
  • Stem villi
  • Fetal blood flowing within the fetal villi

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with a known case of type 1 DM presents with confusion. The blood glucose level is 353 mg/dl and pH-7.0. What is the metabolic abnormality?
questions.solution:
Metabolic abnormality in the above condition is metabolic acidosis. It is due to diabetic ketoacidosis(DKA) which is a complication of type 1 DM.

In DKA, insulin to glucagon ratio is decreased which promotes gluconeogenesis, glycogenolysis, and ketone body formation in the liver. Ketone bodies exist as ketoacids at physiologic pH which are neutralized by bicarbonate. As bicarbonate stores are depleted, metabolic acidosis ensues. Increased lactic acid production also contributes to the acidosis

Diabetic ketoacidosis is an acute complication of type 1 diabetes mellitus. The symptoms include nausea, vomiting, and severe abdominal pain.

Signs:

  • Kussmaul breathing
  • Fruity odor on the patient’s breath
  • Tachycardia
  • Dehydration
  • Hypotension

Blood parameters:

  • Hyperglycemia – 250 – 600 mg%
  • Pseudohyponatremia- There is 1.6-mmol/L reduction in serum sodium level for each 5.6-mmol/L rise in the serum glucose level.
  • Overall total-body K+ deficit, however, the serum K+ at presentation may be mildly elevated, secondary to the acidosis
  • Osmolality– 300–320 mOsm/kg
  • Plasma ketones– Positive
  • Metabolic acidosis– Increased anion gap
  • Serum bicarbonate <15 meq/L– Best initial investigation
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Hyperamylasemia

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: A male patient presents to the emergency department after a car crash. On examination, his BP was 80/40mmHg and pulses were feeble, neck veins distended, and heart sounds were muffled. Which of the following changes will you expect in the jvp of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and distended neck vein suggests a diagnosis of cardiac tamponade. The JVP finding most likely to be seen is absent y descent.

Cardiac tamponade is the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space. It results in the obstruction of the blood flow into the ventricles.

This manifests as Beck's triad which consists of the following: 

  • Distended neck veins (due to decreased venous return)
  • Muffled heart sounds (fluid accumulation in the pericardial space)
  • Hypotension

The physical examination findings in a patient with cardiac tamponade are:

  • Tachycardia
  • Hypotension
  • Elevated JVP
  • Pulsus paradoxus

JVP will have a prominent x (early systolic) descent but an absent y (early diastolic) descent because of the limited or absent early diastolic filling of the ventricle. JVP is almost always elevated in cardiac tamponade and may be associated with venous distention in the forehead and scalp. There may be reductions in the amplitude of the QRS complexes, and electrical alternans of the P, QRS, or T waves in cardiac tamponade.

 

An eFAST is reliable and will show fluid in the pericardial space. A chest X-ray will show an enlarged heart shadow.

Cardiac tamponade can also be treated with open surgery procedures like sternotomy or left thoracotomy. This also allows for the heart to be repaired during the procedure.

questions.text: A patient with suspected tubal pregnancy underwent transvaginal ultrasound which was inconclusive. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the next step would be to confirm the tubal ectopic by measuring serum β hCG. This can be used to differentiate tubal ectopic pregnancy from missed abortion and early intrauterine pregnancy. 

If the level is ≥2000 IU/L, ectopic pregnancy is suspected. If the level is <1500 IU/L, a repeat serum β hCG is taken after 48 hours. If the levels are:

  • Doubled - early intrauterine pregnancy
  • Decreased - abortion
  • Increased but less than doubled value - ectopic pregnancy

Investigations for ectopic pregnancy:

  • Serum β hCG - lower levels compared to normal pregnancy, prolonged doubling time
  • Transvaginal ultrasound - empty uterine cavity, fluid in pouch of Douglas, adnexal mass
  • Colour Doppler - ring of fire pattern
  • Laparoscopy 
  • Dilatation and curettage - decidua identified without villi
  • Serum progesterone 
  • Culdocentesis 

Diagnostic laparoscopy may be done when the diagnosis is still uncertain after serial β-hCG monitoring and repeat ultrasonography. In high-risk situations, such as a history of previous ectopic pregnancy, earlier diagnostic laparoscopy is considered.

questions.text: An elderly male patient presented with a sudden onset of scrotal pain and discharge. Based on the image below, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of an elderly male patient with sudden-onset scrotal pain and discharge, with the image showing a blackish discoloration of the scrotum, is likely to be Fournier's gangrene. 

Fournier's gangrene is an uncommon polymicrobial infection involving the perineal soft tissue, external genitalia, and perianal region. There is subcutaneous tissue inflammation leading to obliterative arteritis and gangrene. It typically follows minor injuries or procedures in the perineal area, urethral dilatation, and injection for hemorrhoids are some of the etiological factors. 

Clinically, sudden scrotal pain with associated prostration, pallor, and pyrexia can be seen. Other features such as crepitus and foul-smelling exudate can be present. 

Emergency surgical debridement is needed after initial measures like fluid resuscitation and broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics are undertaken. Urinary diversion and other supportive measures are useful in the management of the condition. 

Other options:

Option A: Torsion of testis is a surgical emergency typically seen in the age group of 10-25 years. It is characterized by sudden groin and lower abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Examination findings reveal a swollen, tender scrotum and testis with a twisted tender cord above it and loss of cremasteric reflex. 

Option B: Acute epididymo-orchitis is an infection of the epididymis and testis. It is seen in sexually-active young men. In older men, it is seen following a urinary tract infection, secondary to an indwelling catheter. The features include groin ache, fever, swollen and painful epididymis and testis.

Option C: Scrotal carcinoma is a rare carcinoma that is seen in workers exposed to oil, coal products, and aromatic hydrocarbons. It starts as a wart or ulcer in the scrotum and can extend to the testis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravidae at 38 weeks gestation presents to the antenatal clinic with complaints of faintness on lying down for the past one week.  She feels better when she turns to a side and while in sitting position.  What is the reason for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
This is a case of IVC compression known as supine hypotension syndrome (postural hypotension).

  • During late pregnancy, the gravid uterus produces a compression effect on the IVC when the patient is in supine position. In majority of pregnants, to compensate/avoid this effect there will be opening up of collaterals of paravertebral/Azygous veins.
  • When there is failure of opening up of collaterals, venous return of the heart is curtailed leading to hypotension, tachycardia and syncope.
  • The normal BP is quickly restored by turning the patient to lateral position.Hence pregnant females are adviced to lie in lateral positions (left lateral is better).

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presented to the OPD with the findings. He had suffered a fall on an outstretched hand one year back. What is the diagnosis?

choices.text: An undisplaced supracondylar fracture of humerus
Malunion of a supracondylar fracture of humerus

questions.solution:
The history of falling on an outstretched hand along with the gunstock deformity as seen in the image below are suggestive of malunion of a supracondylar fracture of the humerus. 

Cubitus varus deformity or gun stock deformity is a complication of supracondylar humerus fracture that occurs due to malunion. When the distal fragment unites with an excessive backward tilt, there is hyperextension at the elbow.

Supracondylar fractures are the most common fractures in children younger than the age of 7 years. It typically occurs due to a fall on an outstretched arm. They can be of various types as listed below:

  • Posterior displacement of distal fracture fragment occurs commonly and is an extension type of fracture.
  • Anterior displacement of distal fracture fragment is less common and occurs due to a direct blow on a flexed elbow and is often unstable
  • Lateral condylar fractures are due to a varus force on an extended elbow and may extend through the unossified portion of the capitellum into the joint space.

Other options:

Option A: An undisplaced fracture may show a triangular lucency like the sail of a yacht (sail sign), also called a fat pad sign. This is due to the fat pad around the elbow being pushed forward by the hematoma. Also, it would not present with the gun stock deformity.

Option C: The dislocated radial head would present with a discontinuity in the line drawn along the shaft of the proximal radius (the line should normally pass through the capitellum).

Option D: Proximal humerus fractures are uncommon in children and will be pathological fractures (due to reasons such as the presence of a bone cyst)

questions.text: A male patient, a chronic smoker, presents with persistent productive cough, yellow in color and clubbing. On examination, his cough increases with postural changes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of bronchiectasis. Bronchiectasis refers to an irreversible airway dilation that involves the lung in either a focal or a diffuse manner. 

It is caused by the destruction of smooth muscle and elastic tissue due to complications from infections, congenital conditions, or autoimmune disorders.

There are 4 morphological types:

  1. Tubular or cylindrical type
  2. Cystic type
  3. Varicose type
  4. Traction bronchiectasis - seen in interstitial lung disease and is associated with fibrosis

Clinically, they have a cough with excessive foul-smelling mucopurulent sputum, clubbing, crackles, and rhonchi.

Treatment of bronchiectasis

  • Antibiotic treatment targeting the causative pathogen (most common: H. influenzae and P. aeruginosa) should be administered for a minimum of 10–14 days.
  • NTM infection: a macrolide (clarithromycin and azithromycin) combined with rifampin and ethambutol.
  • Mucolytic administration: The mucolytic dornase (DNase) is recommended routinely in CF-related bronchiectasis, but not in non-CF bronchiectasis, given concerns about potential harm in the non-CF population.
  • Bronchial hygiene
  • Hydration
  • Aerosolization of bronchodilators.
  • Hyperosmolar agents (e.g., hypertonic saline).
  • Chest physiotherapy.
  • Pulmonary rehabilitation.
  • Refractory cases: Resection of a focal area of suppuration, lung transplantation.

HRCT is the investigation of choice - most specific.

HRCT findings in bronchiectasis

  • The signet ring sign is seen when the dilated bronchus and accompanying pulmonary artery branch are seen in cross-section. The bronchus and artery should be the same size, whereas, in bronchiectasis, the bronchus is 1.5 times the size of the adjacent vessel.
  • Thickened secretions are seen as tree-in-bud pattern.
  • Tram track sign is seen due to lack of peripheral tapering of the bronchus. 
  • String of beads appearance is seen as alternate dilatation and constriction in varicose bronchiectasis. 
  • Cluster of grapes appearance is seen as cysts emanating from the bronchial wall in cystic bronchiectasis.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with difficulty in swallowing both solids and liquids. A barium swallow revealed the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the barium swallow showing a bird beak appearance is suggestive of achalasia cardia. 

Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder. It is characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) in response to swallowing. 

The patients present with dysphagia, regurgitation, and weight loss. The dysphagia initially begins with liquid foods and then progresses to solid foods. As the food gets accumulated in the esophagus, patients may complain of halitosis. With further progression of the disease, the patients may develop pneumonia, lung abscess, etc.

The initial diagnosis is made by barium swallow or endoscopy, which shows the presence of dilated esophagus due to the constriction of the lower esophageal sphincter (bird-beak appearance). The gold standard test to confirm achalasia cardia is esophageal manometry.

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

questions.text: A 30 year old multigravida at 35 weeks of gestation came to the Opd for regular checkup. In this patient, which of the following Leopold’s maneuvers is done to assess the lie of the fetus ?
questions.solution:
Leopold’s 1 i.e. fundal grip is used to assess fetal lie.

Fetal pole, lie, presenting part, engagement, and attitude of fetal head are assessed by Leopold's maneuvers.

Leopold’s maneuvers are done by four obstetric grips:

  1. Leopold’s 1 (Fundal grip): It assesses the uterine fundus. It helps identification of fetal lie and determination of fetal pole that is cephalic or podalic-occupies with the fundus. The breech gives the sensation of a large, nodular mass, whereas the head feels hard and round and is more mobile.
  2. Leopold’s 2 (Lateral grip): It assesses the fetal orientation. The second maneuver is accomplished as the palms are placed on either side of the maternal abdomen, and gentle but deep pressure is exerted. On one side, a hard, resistant structure is felt-the back. On the other, numerous small, irregular, mobile parts are felt-the fetal extremities. By noting whether the back is directed anteriorly, transversely, or posteriorly, fetal orientation can be determined.
  3. Leopold’s 3 (Pawlik's grip/1st pelvic grip): It assesses the presenting part. The thumb and fingers of one hand grasp the lower portion of the maternal abdomen just above the symphysis pubis. If the presenting part is not engaged, a movable mass will be felt, usually the head.
  4. Leopold’s 4 (2nd pelvic grip): It assesses the engagement and attitude of the fetal head. The examiner faces the mother's feet, and the fingertips of both hands are positioned on either side of the presenting part. They exert inward pressure and then slide along the axis of the pelvic inlet.
