questions.text: A 65-year-old man presented with chronic pain in his hand, knees, and hips,aggravated on climbing stairs, while pain in his hands increases when he writes or types. He also complains of stiffness in his joints in the morning, which lasts for around half an hour. On examination of the hands, Herbeden's and Bouchard's nodes are visible. X-ray of the knee showed narrowed joint space with osteophytes. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of osteoarthritis (OA).

 Osteoarthritis is the most common cause of chronic knee pain in persons aged over 45 years. The early phases typically present with episodic joint pain following overactive use of the diseased joint. As the disease progresses, the pain becomes continuous and may be associated with stiffness of the affected joint. Morning stiffness if present, is usually brief for around 30 minutes. Clinical signs include: 

  • Tenderness of the joint
  • Bony swelling
  • Decreased and painful range of movement 
  • Crepitus when the joint is moved
  • Weakness and wasting of muscles acting on the joint
  • Signs of inflammation 
  • Deformity and instability in severe cases

 The joints involved in osteoarthritis are:

  • Distal and proximal interphalangeal joints (DIP, PIP)
  • First carpometacarpal joint (base of the thumb)
  • Hip
  • Knee
  • First metatarsal phalangeal joint (MTP)
  • Cervical and lumbosacral spine

The wrist, elbow, and ankle joints are usually spared.Heberden’s and Bouchard’s nodes are nodules in osteoarthritis that are palpable in the distal interphalangeal joint and proximal interphalangeal joints respectively.

The characteristic features of OA seen on plain radiographs are:

  • Marginal osteophyte formation
  • Localized joint space narrowing
  • Sclerosis of the underlying bone
  • Subchondral bone cysts
  • Loose bodies and chondrocalcinosis

The image below is an X-ray of osteorthritis showing the presence of osteophytes, narrowing of the joint space (arrow), and subchondral bone sclerosis.

questions.text: Which of the following radioactive isotopes is used for teletherapy?
questions.solution:
Cobalt-60 emits high-energy gamma rays and is commonly used in radiation therapy machines called cobalt units or teletherapy units. These units deliver radiation from outside the body, targeting the tumor.

Other options:

A) Iodine-125: This radioactive isotope is commonly used in brachytherapy for treating prostate cancer. It emits low-energy gamma rays that can effectively target and treat the cancerous tissue.

C) I-131 is a beta-emitter that is taken up by thyroid tissue as well as differentiated thyroid cancers and is used for systemic radiotherapy.

D) Iridium-192: This is a commonly used radioactive isotope in brachytherapy. It emits high-energy gamma rays and is used for treating various types of cancer, such as cervical, prostate, and breast cancer. Iridium-192 is often used in temporary brachytherapy, where the radioactive source is temporarily placed in the body and then removed after a specific period of treatment.

In summary, while Iodine-125 and Iridium-192 are commonly used in brachytherapy, Cobalt-60 is primarily used in external beam radiation therapy. Iodine-131 is used in other medical applications, such as thyroid cancer treatment and diagnostic imaging.

questions.text: Which one of the following is NOT a feature of refeeding syndrome?
questions.solution:
Refeeding syndrome is associated with Hypophosphataemia, hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia.

Refeeding syndrome is a potentially lethal condition that can occur with rapid and excessive feeding of patients with severe underlying malnutrition due to starvation, alcoholism, delayed nutritional support, anorexia nervosa, or massive weight loss in obese patients.

  • It can occur with either enteral or parenteral nutrition, but is more common with the latter.
  • Symptoms: Electrolyte abnormalities can result in cardiac failure and dysrrhythmias, respiratory failure, neu­rologic disturbances, and renal and hepatic dysfunction.

Prevention and treatment:

  • Correct underlying electrolyte and volume deficits.
  • Additionally, thiamine should be administered before the initiation of feeding. Caloric replenition should be instituted slowly and should gradually increase over the first week.
  • Vital signs, fluid balance, and electrolytes should be closely monitored and any deficits corrected as they evolve.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man has the following lesion over the face. He complains of bleeding while itching. Which of the following is seen in the lesion?
questions.solution:
The given history with the image showing an ulcer over the face with pearly, rolled-out borders points to a diagnosis of basal cell carcinoma.

Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is an epithelial tumor arising from basal cells. It is the most common type of skin cancer most commonly seen over the face, above the line joining corner of the mouth, and lobule of the ear. Risk factors for BCC include ultraviolet radiation (strongest risk factor), age 40-80 years with excessive sun exposure, light-skinned people, and exposure to arsenic compounds, coal tar, aromatic hydrocarbons, and infrared light. It is more common in males than females. It is also associated with syndromes such as xeroderma pigmentosum and Gorlin's syndrome.

Features of BCC include:

  • Pearly nodule with rolled border
  • Tortuous telangiectatic vessels 
  • Surface which can get ulcerated with raised and beaded edge, often with a central depression or umbilication
  • Bleeding on minor trauma

BCC has various subtypes such as nodular (most common type), pigmented, nodulocystic, morphoeic, infiltrative, and fibroepithelioma of Pinkus. 

It is locally aggressive and can erode the bone or facial sinuses. It rarely metastasizes via lymph nodes.

The occasional presence of melanin in the nodular variant of BCC (pigmented BCC) may lead to confusion with melanoma.

Diagnosis is confirmed by a wedge biopsy. X-ray or CT may be needed if there is a local invasion. Histology shows peripheral palisading of cells.

Treatment: 

  • Surgical: Wide excision (4-6 mm clearance) with a skin graft or flap or primary suturing 
  • Mohs' surgery for BCC close to the eyes, nose, or ear to preserve more tissue.
  • Non-surgical: Radiotherapy, vismodegib and sonedegib.

questions.text: Which of the following is a punishable offence with regard to MTP guidelines?

choices.text: MTP done up to 24 weeks of pregnancy
MTP done at government authorized center
Non entry in MTP register & not sending reports to DHS

questions.solution:
A register for recording the details of medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) must be kept for at least 5 years and reports must be sent to the Department of Health Services (DHS).

A register for recording the details of medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) must be kept for at least 5 years, from the end of the calendar year it relates to. The patient's name must not be entered; only the reference number is used.

Unlawful disclosure of a patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment with or without a fine. Only the patient's consent is required for MTP; her male partner's consent is not required. Consent of parent/guardian is needed if the age of the patient is <18 years or if the patient is mentally ill.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male was on maize as a staple diet for a prolonged period. He presented with diarrhoea and lesion over his neck as shown in the image below. The condition occurs due to deficiency of:
questions.solution:
The above history and clinical features suggest niacin/vitamin B3 deficiency.

Excessive consumption of maize-based diets can cause pellagra. Corn/Maize has low levels of niacin and tryptophan. Jowar has high leucine content which inhibits QPRTase, an enzyme in the synthesis of Niacin.

Niacin deficiency leads to a disease called pellagra which is characterized by

  • Diarrhea
  • Dermatitis
  • Dementia

The lesion in the neck is characteristic Casal’s necklace pattern, seen in pellagra. The Casal's collar or Casal's necklace is a clinical sign in which there is an erythematous pigmented skin rash in the distribution of a broad collar (dermatomes C3 and C4).

questions.text: A male patient complains of loss of appetite and dysphagia. He lost around significant amount weight in the last few months. The clinician suspects an esophageal condition. Which of the following is the gold standard investigation method in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with a significant weight loss and other symptoms of cachexia and anorexia most likely has esophageal carcinoma. Endoscopy and biopsy of the lesion (gold standard) are performed to diagnose esophageal carcinoma.

Esophageal carcinoma is more commonly seen in men. Tobacco use and alcohol are strong risk factors. Adenocarcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus are the two most common types. The squamous cell variant usually affects the upper two-thirds and the adenocarcinoma variant usually affects the lower third. The incidence of adenocarcinoma is increasing.

Clinical features include:

  • Dysphagia (most common)
  • Regurgitation
  • Vomiting
  • Odynophagia
  • Weight loss

In the advanced stage, there can be hoarseness of voice due to recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy, horner’s syndrome, chronic spinal pain, and diaphragmatic paralysis.

Flexible endoscopy with biopsy is preferred for confirmation of diagnosis. Other investigations include barium swallow, which shows a rat-tail appearance due to irregular narrowing or ulceration. Contrast-enhanced CT and PET can be used to assess distant metastasis. Endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) is the investigation of choice to assess tumor invasion and lymph node metastasis.

questions.text: A G2P1, 38 weeks of gestation age, presented for delivery. Her last pregnancy was uncomplicated, and she underwent a cesarean section. Now, she wants to have a vaginal birth. The clinician decided to perform a TOLAC (trial of labor after cesarean). Which of the following has the least risk for this procedure?
questions.solution:
In the context of attempting a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC), the risk associated with a low segment transverse incision is relatively lower compared to other options.

A low segment transverse incision (also known as a low transverse or Pfannenstiel incision) during the previous cesarean delivery is typically associated with a lower risk of uterine rupture during a subsequent TOLAC compared to other types of uterine incisions, such as a classical or vertical incision.

Other options:

Breech presentation during labor after previous cesarean delivery may increase the risk of uterine rupture and is generally considered a contraindication for TOLAC. 

Preeclampsia is a pregnancy complication characterized by high blood pressure and signs of organ damage, typically occurring after 20 weeks of gestation. While preeclampsia can pose risks during pregnancy and delivery, it is not specifically related to the risk associated with a previous LSCS and TOLAC.

A classical cesarean section involves a vertical incision on the upper portion of the uterus. This type of incision carries a higher risk of uterine rupture during a subsequent TOLAC compared to a low segment transverse incision, making it a less favorable option for attempting TOLAC.

questions.text: A patient has profuse bleeding after the removal of an IV cannula. He underwent a small bowel resection and was given broad-spectrum antibiotics during his hospital stay. The deficiency of which of the following vitamins is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The deficiency of vitamin K is responsible for this condition.

Vitamin K deficiency in adults may be seen in patients with chronic small-intestinal diseases like celiac disease, Crohn’s disease, obstructed biliary tracts, and after small-bowel resection. Additionally, broad-spectrum antibiotics can precipitate Vitamin K deficiency by reducing the number of gut bacteria, which synthesize menaquinones.

It is a fat-soluble vitamin that has two natural forms: Vitamin K1, also known as phylloquinone, from vegetable sources, and vitamin K2, or menaquinones, which are synthesized by bacterial flora and found in hepatic tissue.

Vitamin K is required for the posttranslational carboxylation of glutamic acid, which is necessary for calcium binding to γ-carboxylated proteins such as

  • prothrombin (factor II)
  • factors VII, IX, and X
  • protein C, protein S

Patients with vitamin K deficiency usually present with a history of bleeding either at venipuncture sites or minor trauma.

It is diagnosed on the basis of an elevated prothrombin time or reduced clotting factors. It is treated with supplementation by oral or IV route.

Other options:

Option A: Riboflavin or Vitamin B2 deficiency manifests as angular stomatitis, magenta tongue, seborrhea, corneal vascularization. It is seen in alcoholism, and individuals with a poor diet and decreased intake of dairy products.

Option B: Vitamin E deficiency manifests as peripheral neuropathy, spinocerebellar ataxia, skeletal muscle atrophy, and retinopathy. Usually seen with fat malabsorption or genetic abnormalities of vitamin E metabolism.

Option C: Niacin deficiency manifests as pellagra, which includes symptoms of diarrhea, a pigmented rash over sun-exposed areas, bright red tongue, memory loss, and altered sensorium. Alcoholism, vitamin B6 deficiency, riboflavin, and tryptophan deficiencies predispose to this condition.

choices.text: Serum calcium >1 mg/dL above the upper limits of normal

questions.solution:
Creatinine clearance <90 mL/min is not an indication of parathyroidectomy in primary hyperparathyroidism.

Indications for parathyroidectomy in asymptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism:

questions.text: A female patient is diagnosed with recurrent genital infections. In which of the conditions does her male partner need to be treated?
questions.solution:
The male partner should be treated with a single dose of oral metronidazole in cases of recurrent Trichomonas infection.

Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the protozoan parasite Trichomonas vaginalis. It can cause symptoms such as vaginal discharge, itching, and irritation in females, and urethritis or prostatitis in males.

Since trichomoniasis is transmitted through sexual contact, both partners should be treated simultaneously to prevent reinfection.

The treatment options in case of Trochomoniasis include:

  • An oral dose of metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days or single oral dose of metronidazole 2 g  
  • Vinegar douche to lower the vaginal PH
  • Trichofuran suppositories
  • Betadine gel

Other Options:

  • Bacterial vaginosis is an imbalance of bacteria in the vagina and is not typically considered a sexually transmitted infection. Treatment of male partners is not routinely recommended. 
  • Candida albicans is the fungus responsible for most cases of vaginal yeast infections (vulvovaginal candidiasis). It is not considered a sexually transmitted infection, and treatment of male partners is generally not necessary unless they have symptoms of a yeast infection.
  • Herpes is a viral infection caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV). While it can be sexually transmitted, the treatment of male partners may not be routinely necessary unless they are also infected or experiencing symptoms of genital herpes.

questions.text: In a patient with NSTEMI, all the following can be used for treatment except?
questions.solution:
Streptokinase is not used in the management of NSTEMI. It is a fibrin nonspecific plasminogen activator used as a fibrinolytic agent in the treatment of STEMI.

Unlike STEMI, fibrinolytic therapy is not used in the management of NSTEMI. This is because STEMI is almost always caused by plaque rupture leading to the formation of an occluding thrombus, whereas, NSTEMI can be caused by a stable non-occluding plaque with some amount of lumen still patent. Fibrinolytic therapy may lead to the rupture of the stable plaque-causing more damage.

Acute coronary syndrome is commonly classified into:

  • Unstable angina
  • NSTEMI (Non-ST segment elevation MI)
  • STEMI (ST-segment elevation MI)

The treatment of NSTEMI is as follows:

  • Admission to a specialized cardiac unit
  • Inhaled oxygen
  • Bed rest with continuous ECG monitoring
  • Monitoring cardiac biomarkers
  • Nitrates
  • Beta-blockers
  • Antiplatelet drugs like aspirin, clopidogrel, prasugrel

questions.text: The most common cause of bladder outlet obstruction in a male child is
questions.solution:
The most common cause of bladder outflow obstruction in a male child is the posterior urethral valve (PUV). 

PUV is a membranous fold in the posterior urethra. They typically lie just distal to the verumontanum. It is the most common cause of bladder outlet obstruction in male newborns. PUV is thought to be due to the persistence of the urogenital membrane. 

Urethral obstruction will result in a dilated posterior urethral valve, dilated bladder, and bilateral hydronephrosis. Prenatally this appears as a keyhole sign during the ultrasound. It can also result in oligohydramnios. If the defect is not detected prenatally, they present postnatally either as a newborn or young infant with urinary tract symptoms, abdominal distension, or respiratory distress due to lung hypoplasia.

Untreated PUV may lead to chronic kidney disease, bladder dysfunction, and vesicoureteral reflux. 

Diagnosis is presumed by the presence of an elongated posterior valve during the voiding phase of the voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG).

The image shows a keyhole sign as seen in PUV prenatally. The white arrow points to the main hole and represents the distended urinary bladder. The black arrow points to the slit, which is the distended proximal urethra.

 

Other options

Options B and C- Urethral atresia and anterior urethral valve are rare congenital anomalies that can also lead to urinary obstruction.

Option D- Ureterocele is the cystic enlargement of the intramural ureter. It is common in females. They can present with features of urinary tract infection, bladder obstruction, or ureteral stones. Excretion urography will show cobra head appearance.

The image shown below depicts the "cobra head" sign in a patient with bilateral ureterocele.

questions.text: A patient involved in a road traffic accident (RTA) presents with signs of seat belt abdominal trauma on the anterior abdominal wall. What should be the primary concern in terms of potential injuries?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a seat belt injury most likely indicates a hollow viscus injury. In cases of blunt abdominal trauma, particularly those involving seat belt injuries, there is a risk of sustaining injuries to the hollow viscera, which includes organs such as the stomach, small intestine, large intestine, and bladder.

Seat belt injuries can lead to compression forces against the abdomen, potentially causing shearing or tearing injuries to these structures.

Hollow viscus injuries can be challenging to diagnose clinically and may require imaging studies such as CT scans or exploratory surgery for confirmation.

Other Options:

Options A & B: While liver and spleen injuries are also common in blunt abdominal trauma, especially in cases of seat belt injuries, the question specifies signs of seat belt abdominal trauma on the anterior abdominal wall, which suggests a concern beyond these solid organs.

Option C: While the pancreas can be injured in cases of blunt abdominal trauma, the primary concern in this scenario, given the history of RTA and signs of seat belt abdominal trauma, should be focused on potential injuries to hollow viscera rather than the pancreas specifically.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman receiving cyclosporin A after renal transplantation develops multiple and bilateral breast lumps that regress after cessation of treatment. ​Biopsy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Almost half the women receiving cyclosporin A after renal transplantation develop multiple and bilateral fibroadenomas that regress after cessation of treatment.

Fibroadenomas are the most common benign tumor of the female breast. They are frequently multiple and bilateral and usually occur in women<30 years of age. They are called "breast mouse" due to their high mobility within the breast.

Complex fibroadenomas are grouped with “proliferative changes without atypia” and are associated with 1.5-2 times increased risk of subsequent cancer. Complex fibroadenomas contain cysts larger than 0.3 cm, sclerosing adenosis, epithelial calcifications, or papillary apocrine change.

Histological image of Fibroadenoma showing proliferation of ducts arranged in intracanalicular (compressed) and pericanalicular pattern surrounded by fibromyxoid stroma.

questions.text: A newborn is seen to have an abnormal lump in the lower back. Identify the condition from the MRI given below.
questions.solution:
The MRI demonstrates meningocele.

Meningocele is formed when meninges herniate through a defect in the posterior vertebral arches. Patients present with a fluctuant midline mass that is covered with skin. Transillumination through the swelling may be present.

Other options:

Option B: Myelomeningocele is a severe form of incomplete fusion of the vertebral column. Meninges and spinal cord herniate through the gap. Patients commonly present with a lumbosacral defect covered by a thin layer of epithelialized tissue. It is associated with flaccid paralysis of lower limbs.

Option C: Spina bifida occulta is a midline defect of the vertebral bodies without protrusion of the spinal cord or meninges.

Option D: Lissencephaly is a disorder characterized by a lack of cerebral convolutions.

questions.text: The most common tumor of the parotid gland is ______.
questions.solution:
The most common tumor of the parotid gland is pleomorphic adenoma.

  • 80 to 90% of parotid gland tumors are benign; most commonly, they are pleomorphic adenomas.
  • Most commonly, they arise from the superficial lobe, and all tumors of the superficial lobe of the parotid gland should be managed by superficial parotidectomy.
  • Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the parotid gland.

Pleomorphic adenoma:

  • Slowly growing benign tumor
  • Unicentric in origin
  • Pseudo-capsule present
  • Potentially malignant
  • Possibility of protrusion of fringes of the tumor mass through the capsule
  • Radioresistant
  • Usually affects adults, females > males
  • Slowly growing, painless swelling
  • Well-defined margins
  • Lobulated, firm, elastic-to-hard consistency
  • Free from deeper structures
  • No facial nerve involvement
  • Deep lobe pushes tonsils and faucial pillars

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: BIPAP cannot be considered in patients with which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
Patients being unconscious in considered a contraindication for BiPAP.

BiPAP (Bilevel Positive Airway Pressure) therapy is a non-invasive ventilation technique that requires patient cooperation and the ability to breathe spontaneously. It relies on the patient's ability to initiate and maintain breathing efforts while receiving pressure support from the device. An unconscious patient, by definition, lacks the ability to consciously control their breathing and cannot actively participate in the breathing process. Therefore, BiPAP therapy is contraindicated in unconscious patients as they cannot tolerate the interface and settings required for this type of ventilation.

In such cases, invasive mechanical ventilation, which provides full ventilatory support, is typically necessary to maintain adequate gas exchange and support respiratory function.

Other Options:

(a) Low pO2 levels: BiPAP therapy is often utilized to improve oxygenation in patients with hypoxemia (low blood oxygen levels). By delivering positive airway pressure, BiPAP helps to recruit collapsed alveoli, improve lung ventilation-perfusion matching, and enhance oxygen diffusion into the bloodstream. Therefore, low pO2 levels are not a contraindication for BiPAP therapy; instead, they may indicate the need for BiPAP to support oxygenation.

(c) High CO2 levels: BiPAP therapy can also be beneficial for patients with hypercapnia (elevated blood carbon dioxide levels), such as those with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation or obesity hypoventilation syndrome. By providing inspiratory pressure support and positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP), BiPAP assists ventilation, enhances alveolar ventilation, and helps to eliminate excess carbon dioxide from the body. Therefore, high CO2 levels alone do not contraindicate the use of BiPAP therapy; rather, BiPAP may be indicated to improve ventilation and reduce CO2 levels.

(d) Obstructive sleep apnea: BiPAP therapy is commonly employed as a non-invasive treatment for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), a sleep disorder characterized by recurrent episodes of upper airway collapse during sleep. By delivering two levels of pressure – higher pressure during inspiration (IPAP) and lower pressure during expiration (EPAP) – BiPAP helps to keep the upper airway open, prevent apnea events, and improve sleep quality. Therefore, obstructive sleep apnea is not a contraindication for BiPAP therapy; rather, BiPAP is a recommended treatment modality for managing this condition.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen on the microscopy in patients with lichen planus?
questions.solution:
Colloid bodies can be seen on microscopy in patients with lichen planus.

Lichen planus (LP) is an idiopathic inflammatory disease affecting the skin and mucous membrane. Microscopy will show :

  • Acanthosis of the epidermis.
  • Irregular thickening of the granular layer.
  • Hyperkeratosis.
  • Colloid (civatte) bodies due to degenerating basal epidermal cells. 
  • Sawtooth appearance of rete ridges.
  • Max Joseph spaces due to focal separation from the dermis.
  • Band‐like infiltrate of lymphocytes and histiocytes near the dermo-epidermal junction.

Patients present with pruritic, purple, polygonal, papules. The lesions have thin white lines on their surface known as Wickham’s striae. They are commonly seen on the volar aspect of the wrists, the lumbar region, and around the ankles.

The mucosal involvement is also seen. The commonest mucosal sites are buccal mucosa and tongue, rarely it can also be found on the anus and genitalia. 

Nail involvement can be seen as thinning of nail plate leading to an exaggeration of longitudinal lines, and linear depressions. The nails can also be destroyed leading to anonychia. Involvement of nail bed may give rise to longitudinal melanonychia, hyperpigmentation, subungual hyperkeratosis, or onycholysis.

Other options

Option A- Pautrier's microabscess is the intraepidermal lymphocytic microabscess in the absence of marked spongiosis. The cells within the epidermis may show nuclear hyperchromatism or atypia. It is seen in Mycosis fungoides.

The image below shows atypical lymphocytes showing epidermotropism and the formation of Pautrier's microabscesses in mycosis fungoides.

 

Option B- Munro microabscess is the accumulation of neutrophils in the stratum corneum. The lesions present as well-demarcated red scaly plaques. They might have a circle of clear zone around it which is known as the Woronoff ring. This finding is seen in psoriasis.

Option D- Michaelis–Gutmann bodies are large, foamy macrophages mixed with occasional multinucleate giant cells and lymphocytes. It occurs due to defective phagosomes presenting as basophilic concretions. These are pathognomonic of malakoplakia. Grossly, malakoplakia appears as soft, yellow, slightly raised mucosal plaques.

  • Radial head fracture
  • Fracture coronoid process of ulna

questions.text: A young male patient was given regional block with 0.25% bupivacaine for a minor surgical procedure. Shortly after the injection, the patient suddenly became unresponsive and the pulse was not recordable. Which of the following would be the best course of management for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of an unresponsive patient with an absent pulse following bupivacaine administration is most likely due to bupivacaine-induced cardiotoxicity resulting from accidental intravascular injection of local anesthetic. The best course of management in this scenario would be administering CPR (cardiopulmonary resuscitation), along with a 20% intralipid injection.

Bupivacaine is a long-acting local anesthetic that is the most cardiotoxic among the local anesthetics. It depresses the rapid phase of depolarization in Purkinje fibers and ventricular muscle due to a decreased availability of fast sodium channels in cardiac membranes. This reduced rate of depolarization depresses myocardial contractility. Hence, bupivacaine is a potent cardio depressant.

Cardio-vascular effects of bupivacaine-induced toxicity are as follows:

  • Left ventricular depression
  • Atrioventricular heart block
  • Ventricular arrhythmias and ventricular fibrillation
  • Sinus bradycardia can lead to cardiac arrest

Initial management includes immediate initiation of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and defibrillation as per the advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) algorithm.

Following CPR, intralipid therapy is initiated. Its mechanism is explained by the lipid sink theory which states lipophilic drugs (bupivacaine) are absorbed into the lipid emulsion of the plasma, hence, removed from tissues affected by toxicity.

A rapid bolus of intralipid 20% IV (1.5 mL/kg) is administered without delay, followed by an infusion of 0.25 mL/kg/min. The infusion should be given continuously for at least 10 minutes after hemodynamic stability is achieved. 

Local anesthesia systemic toxicity (LAST) can also affect the central nervous system (CNS), which is more susceptible to local anesthetic action as compared to the cardiovascular system. Dizziness, tinnitus, and disorientation are the initial symptoms. Shivering, muscular twitching, and tremors follow. Tonic-clonic seizures occur. Finally, respiratory depression can lead to respiratory arrest.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man sustained a spinal cord injury as a result of a road traffic accident. On examination, his blood pressure is found to be 90/60 mmHg. The patient most likely suffered from which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of the presence of hypotension associated with the spinal cord injury is suggestive of neurogenic shock.

Neurogenic shock refers to reduced tissue perfusion due to loss of vasomotor tone to peripheral arterial beds. Neurogenic shock is usually secondary to spinal cord injuries due to vertebral body fractures of the cervical or high thoracic region that disrupts the sympathetic regulation of peripheral vascular tone. Loss of vasoconstrictor impulses results in increased vascular capacitance, decreased venous return and decreased cardiac output.

Primary injury in neurogenic shock occurs due to damage to axons and the membrane of neurons. Secondary injury occurs doe to vascular damage hours to days after the primary insult.

The clinical features are bradycardia, temperature dysregulation, hypotension and autonomic dysreflexia. The skin often appears warm and flushed and there is also presence of radiological evidence of vertebral fracture.

Treatment involves securing of airways, adequate ventilation and perfusion with fluids and blood products followed by administration of vasoconstrictors to improve vascular tone. 

Other options:

Option A: Cardiogenic shock is caused due to the failure of the myocardial pump.

Option B: Septic shock is not likely in this clinical scenario, as there is no evidence of any infection.

Option D: Hypovolemic shock is caused due to a significant decrease in blood or plasma volume, caused by the loss of fluid from the vascular compartment. Haemorrhage, fluid loss from severe burns, diarrhea, excessive urine formation, perspiration, and trauma are some of the major mechanisms of fluid loss that can lead to hypovolemic shock.

  • Inferior - inguinal ligament

questions.text: A patient complains of experiencing pain in the calf region after walking a certain distance. He reports that he needs to rest to relieve the pain. Which grade of Boyd's grading system does this symptom correspond to?
questions.solution:
This patient's pain typically resolves with rest. This indicates that he can be classified as Grade III according to Boyd's classification of claudication.

Boyd's grading system is commonly used to classify the severity of peripheral arterial disease (PAD) based on the presence and severity of symptoms.

Grade III corresponds to symptoms of intermittent claudication, where the patient experiences reproducible muscle pain, cramping, or weakness in the lower limbs (usually the calf muscles) after a specific distance of walking or physical activity. The pain typically resolves with rest. Grade III indicates moderate PAD severity.

Boyd's classification of claudication: 

  • Grade I: Patient complains of pain after walking. If the patient continues to walk, due to increased blood flow in muscle and opening of collaterals metabolites causing pain are washed away and the pain subsides.
  • Grade II: Pain still persists on continuing to walk; but can walk with effort.
  • Grade III: The patient has to rest to relieve the pain.
  • Grade IV: Pain at rest.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best method to detect HbA1c?
questions.solution:
Ion exchange chromatography is the best method to estimate HbA1c.

This method separates ionizable molecules according to differences in charge through a column that contains resin-bound charged groups. This is a modified version of high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC).

If the charged group in the column is anionic or negatively charged, the column is called a cation exchanger. Here, molecules with a net positive charge migrate through the matrix more slowly than those with a net negative charge. It is used for the estimation of negatively charged particles such as HbA1c.

Ion exchange chromatography also separates hemoglobin variants into peaks. It has the least interference from other hemoglobin variants. However, it is temperature-dependent.

 

Other options:

Option B: In Electrophoresis the molecules migrate in a solution under the influence of an electric current. It can identify different variants of hemoglobin. However the presence of fetal hemoglobin(HbF) can interfere with the result.

Option C: Immunoassays are used to quantify molecules based on the specificity and selectivity of antibody reagents generated. It can provide quantitative estimates of HbA1c but HbF produces falsely low results and hemoglobin variants such as HbS and HbC may cause a false increase in HbA1c measurements.

Option D: Affinity chromatography is a type of liquid chromatography. Here, the molecules bind to different ligands present in the matrix based on their affinity and gets separated. It is not affected by temperature. High levels of HbF seen in thalassemia may interfere with its result.

questions.text: Inhalational agent of choice for cardiac patients is______
questions.solution:
The inhalational agent of choice for cardiac patients is Isoflurane as the cardiac output is best preserved by it.

Isoflurane has myocardial protective properties, limiting infarct size (ischaemic preconditioning).

Isoflurane has also been implicated in the coronary steal phenomenon as it dilates coronary arteries. But, as long as coronary perfusion pressure is maintained, this phenomenon does not occur. 

Other Options :

Propofol is an IV induction agent.

  • Halothane is associated with a higher incidence of cardiac dysrhythmias and myocardial depression.
  • Desflurane is a sympathomimetic. This is the use-limiting disadvantage of desflurane. 
  • Sevoflurane can decrease sympathetic nervous activity

questions.text: A patient with a known history of lung cancer presents with darkening of the creases in their palms and soles. Which of the following hormones might be the underlying cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario which shows hyperpigmentation in a patient with lung cancer indicates an increased production of MSH. MSH is a peptide hormone that plays a role in regulating pigmentation by stimulating the production of melanin in melanocytes.

In lung cancer, tumors can produce adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), which is structurally similar to MSH.

ACTH can stimulate the release of MSH from the pituitary gland, leading to increased melanin production and subsequent hyperpigmentation of the skin, particularly in areas with increased melanocyte activity such as the palms and soles.

Other Options:

  • Neuropeptide Y is a neurotransmitter involved in various physiological processes, including appetite regulation and stress response. It is not directly associated with pigmentation or hyperpigmentation.
  • Melanin is the pigment responsible for skin coloration. While melanin production can be influenced by hormones like MSH, the presence of melanin alone does not explain the specific hyperpigmentation observed in this case.
  • C-peptide is a byproduct of insulin production and is used as a marker for insulin secretion. It is not directly involved in pigmentation or hyperpigmentation.

questions.text: Amsel's criteria is used in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Amsel's criteria is used in bacterial vaginosis.

According to Amsel's criteria, the discharge has the following characteristics. 

  • White milky non-viscous discharge, adherent to the vaginal wall
  • The pH of the discharge is more than 4.5
  • Fishy odor when mixed with 10% KOH. This is called the Whiff test.
  • Presence of clue cells-the epithelial cells have a fuzzy border due to the adherence of bacteria.
  • Decrease in the number of lactobacilli and increase in the number of Gardnerella and other bacteria.

It is treated with 500 mg of metronidazole twice daily for 7 days.

Shown below is the Gram-stained smear of vaginal discharge of a patient diagnosed with bacterial vaginosis. It reveals vaginal epithelial cells that have a fuzzy border due to the adherence of bacteria. These are called clue cells.

questions.text: In asterixis, which of the following would commonly be seen?
questions.solution:
In asterixis, the condition commonly seen is hypercarbia. Asterixis is frequently observed in patients with hypercarbia, especially in the setting of respiratory failure or COPD, due to its effects on the central nervous system. Therefore, hypercarbia is the most appropriate option among the choices provided.

Other options:

Hypoxia refers to a condition in which there is a deficiency of oxygen reaching the tissues. While hypoxia can lead to various neurological manifestations, asterixis is not typically associated with hypoxia. Asterixis is more commonly observed in conditions affecting the central nervous system or metabolic disturbances.

Thyrotoxicosis is a condition characterized by excessive thyroid hormone levels in the bloodstream, often due to an overactive thyroid gland (hyperthyroidism). Asterixis is not a characteristic feature of thyrotoxicosis. Instead, thyrotoxicosis may present with symptoms such as palpitations, heat intolerance, weight loss, and tremors.

Anxiety neurosis, or anxiety disorder, refers to a group of mental health disorders characterized by excessive worry, fear, and nervousness. Asterixis is not typically associated with anxiety neurosis. While anxiety disorders can manifest with various physical symptoms, asterixis is more commonly observed in neurological or metabolic conditions.

questions.text: A 60-year-old bedridden patient develops acute onset dyspnea and chest pain. A CT pulmonary angiography was done. Which of the following investigations is considered the investigation of choice in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
In a bedridden patient presenting with sudden onset dyspnea and chest pain, there is a concern for possible pulmonary embolism (PE). Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) can be suspected in this patient because of his bedridden status. Duplex ultrasound is the investigation of choice for diagnosis of DVT (Filling defects in flow and lack of compressibility indicate the presence of a thrombosis)

DVT of the leg is complicated by the immediate risk of pulmonary embolus and sudden death. Patients are at risk of developing a post-thrombotic limb and venous ulceration. 

Virchow's Triad: three factors important in the development of venous thrombosis. 

  • Endothelial injury (vascular Injury)
  • Hypercoagulability of blood
  • Stasia or turbulence of blood flow

The most important predisposing factor is hospital admissions for the treatment of a medical or surgical condition

Diagnosis:

  • D-dimer measurement: If normal, no indication for further investigation but if raised, a duplex ultrasound examination of the deep veins should be performed.
  • Duplex ultrasound is the investigation of choice for diagnosis of DVT (Filling defects in flow and lack of compressibility indicate the presence of a thrombosis)
  • Ascending venography shows thrombus as a filling defect, which is now rarely required

Treatment

  • Rest, elevation of the limb, and bandaging the entire limb with a crepe bandage.
  • Anticoagulants: Heparin/low molecular weight heparin, warfarin, phenindione.
  • Palma operation
  • May-Husni operation

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a history of tuberculosis presents with dyspnea on exertion. On examination, it is noted that the JVP rises during inspiration. A chest radiograph of the patient is given below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with a history of tuberculosis now presenting with positive Kussmaul's sign, and pericardial calcification seen on chest radiograph suggest a diagnosis of constrictive pericarditis. 

Constrictive pericarditis is a chronic type of pericarditis that results when there is healing of acute fibrinous pericarditis or absorption of chronic pericardial effusion. While the most common cause in developing countries is tuberculosis, in developed countries, it occurs following viral pericarditis, cardiac surgery, mediastinal irradiation, or as a manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis and SLE. The main abnormality which occurs in constrictive pericarditis is the inability of the ventricles to fill because of the rigid and thickened pericardium. Unlike tamponade, this restriction is not uniform through the diastole. Ventricular filling is normal early in the diastole but stops suddenly when the elastic limit of the pericardium is reached. Y-descent on the JVP curve is prominent in constrictive pericarditis because it represents the rapid early filling of the ventricles. A sudden stop in ventricular filling and subsequent rising pressure is seen as a square root sign in the JVP curve.

The patient presents with exertional dyspnea and orthopnea. There may be a paradoxical rise in venous pressure during inspiration (Kussmaul's sign). Apart from constrictive pericarditis, Kussmaul's sign can be positive in tricuspid stenosis, restrictive cardiomyopathy, right heart failure, and pulmonary embolism. The ECG often shows low-voltage QRS complexes and diffuse flattening of T-waves. A chest radiograph may show pericardial calcification, especially in tuberculous pericarditis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman is being evaluated for bleeding per vagina. She attained menopause at the age of 47. Which of the following is least likely to be a cause of post-menopausal bleeding?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Ovarian Follicular cysts are least likely to be a cause of post-menopausal bleeding. They are usually asymptomatic unless they rupture, hemorrhage or the ovary undergoes torsion which would manifest as an acute abdomen. They occur when there is the failure of absorption of fluid in an incompletely developed follicle or anovulation. 

Postmenopausal bleeding is diagnosed when there is bleeding per vagina after 6 months of amenorrhoea after the age of 40 (menopausal age). 

Causes of postmenopausal bleeding include: 

  • Genital tract trauma (Option A)
  • Cervical erosion, inflammation, polyp, or ulcer
  • Uterus - endometritis, endometrial hyperplasia, endometrial carcinoma (Option C), polyp, or sarcoma
  • Fallopian tube malignancy
  • Ovarian tumors such as Brenner tumor, granulosa cell tumor (Option D)
  • Hypertension and blood dyscrasia
  • Urinary tract trauma, bladder carcinoma
  • Hemorrhoid, anal fissures, and rectal cancers confused as bleeding per vagina
  • Use of estrogens as hormone replacement therapy, tamoxifen.

questions.text: A patient is suspected to have transudative type of pleural effusion. Which of the following pleural fluid findings would not be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Low specific gravity in pleural fluid
Low cellular content in pleural fluid

questions.solution:
This patient has a transudative pleural effusion. High fibrin in pleural fluid in a finding noted in exudative type of pleural effusion, not transudative.

Fibrin is a protein involved in the clotting process. High fibrin levels suggest increased vascular permeability and leakage of proteins into the pleural space, indicative of an exudative process rather than a transudative one.

Light’s criteria can be used to differentiate between transudative and exudative pleural effusions. Exudative effusions will meet at least one of the following criteria:

  • Pleural fluid protein/serum protein >0.5
  • Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH >0.6
  • Pleural fluid LDH is more than two-thirds of the upper limit of normal for serum. 

Other options:

Low protein in pleural fluid: Transudative pleural effusions are typically characterized by low protein levels in the pleural fluid, usually less than 3 g/dL. This is due to the passive filtration of fluid across the pleural membrane in conditions such as congestive heart failure or cirrhosis.

Low specific gravity in pleural fluid: Specific gravity measures the concentration of solutes in a fluid compared to water. In transudative pleural effusions, the specific gravity of the pleural fluid is typically low due to its dilute nature. 

Low cellular content: Transudative pleural effusions are characterized by a low cellular content, typically with few white blood cells and no malignant cells. 

Related Pearl: Types of pleural effusion

Transudative Pleural effusion

  • Congestive heart failure
  • Cirrhosis
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Peritoneal dialysis
  • Superior vena cava obstruction
  • Myxedema 
  • Urinothorax

Exudative Pleural effusion 

  • Neoplastic disease: metastatic disease and mesothelioma
  • Infectious disease
  • Pulmonary embolization
  • GI: Esophageal perforation, pancreatic disease, intraabdominal abscess etc.,
  • Collagen vascular disease: SLE, rheumatoid pleuritis, Wegener's, Churg Strauss syndrome etc.,
  • Post coronary bypass surgery
  • Asbestos exposure
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Drug-induced pleural disease: nitrofurantoin, dantrolene, bromocriptine, amiodarone etc.,
  • Radiation therapy
  • Hemothorax
  • Chylothorax

questions.text: A hypertensive pregnant woman presented with abdominal pain, bleeding per vagina, and loss of fetal movements. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture with abdominal pain, bleeding per vagina, and loss of fetal movements in a hypertensive pregnant woman points to the diagnosis of placental abruption.  

Abruptio placenta is the partial/total separation of a normally implanted placenta before delivery.

The bleeding may be either

  • Revealed - Blood dissects downwards between membranes and uterine wall to escape through the cervix. Or,
  • Concealed -Blood accumulates between the detached placenta and uterus. Or,
  • Mixed

Risk factors for abruption placenta include prior abruption history, preterm premature rupture of membranes, and pregnancy-associated hypertension. The haemorrhage into decidua basalis causes separation and compression of the placenta. This compromises fetal circulation leading to fetal distress.

 Depending upon the degree of placental abruption and its clinical effects, the cases are graded as follows:

Grade 1 Grade 2 Grade 3
Vaginal bleeding is slight Vaginal bleeding mild to moderate Bleeding is moderate to severe or concealed.

Uterus irritable, minimal tenderness

 Uterine tenderness is always present Uterine tenderness is marked.
Maternal BP and fibrinogen unaffected Maternal pulse increased, BP maintained Shock is pronounced
FHS good Fetal distress present Fetal death is the rule
Maternal shock absent Maternal shock absent Associated coagulation defect or anuria may complicate


Placenta previa occurs when the placenta is implanted in the lower uterine segment over or very close to the cervical os. Vaginal bleeding is usually painless in this condition. Fetal condition is generally good until bleeding is severe which occurs in later stages. High-risk factors include multiparty, previous cesarean, or myomectomy scar in the uterus.

In preterm labour, fetal movements are not compromised. Hydramnios does not present with bleeding PV.

questions.text: A 7 year old child is noted to be extremely naughty, unable to sit in a place for a long time, excessively talking, and unable to concentrate on a thing for a long time. Which of the following drug is used in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder(ADHD). The drug of choice for ADHD is Methylphenidate.

Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a neuro­ psychiatric condition characterized by a pattern of diminished attention span and increased impulsivity or hyperactivity. The prefrontal cortex of the brain has been implicated in its etiology and dopamine is the main neurotransmitter. 

ADHD can begin during infancy but is usually rec­ognized between 1-3 years of age. ADHD was known as minimal brain dysfunction earlier. The characteristics of children with ADHD, in order of frequency, are

  • Hyperactivity
  • Attention deficit (short attention span, distractibility)
  • Impulsivity (action before thought, abrupt shifts in activity, lack of organization)
  • Memory and thinking deficits
  • Specific learning disabilities
  • Speech and hearing deficits.

Under DSM-5 criteria, for diagnosis of ADHD, it is necessary for symptoms to be present prior to age 12, persist for at least 6 months, have a negative impact on social, academic, or occupational activities, and be present in two or more settings.

The course of ADHD is variable. The majority of the cases persist into adult life. The hyperactivity may sometimes disappear, but the decreased attention span and impulse-control problems usually persist. Patients with ADHD are vulnerable to antisocial behavior, conduct disorder, substance use disorders, and mood disorders.

Pharmacotherapy is the first line of treatment for ADHD. CNS stimulants are the first-choice agents as they have shown the greatest efficacy with mild tolerable side effects. The CNS stimulants used are dopamine agonists like methylphenidate, amphetamine salts, and dextroamphetamine. Non-stimulant medications used in the treatment of ADHD include atomoxetine (norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor), clonidine, and guanfacine (Alpha agonists).

Psychosocial interventions such as academic organization skills remediation, parent training, behavior modification in the classroom and at home, cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), and social skills training are also used as an adjunct to pharmacotherapy.

Note: Modafinil is used in the management of narcolepsy.

questions.text: A young boy presents to the emergency department after being at a party. Within minutes, he had started to feel his heart race, had profuse sweating and tremors, and was rushed to the hospital. He also reports seeing red halos while listening to music. Which of the following drugs did he most likely consume?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, mimicking a panic attack (bad trip) is suggestive of lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) abuse. 

LSD is the most powerful hallucinogen known to man. Increased sympathetic activity like tachycardia, hypertension, pupillary dilation, tremor, and fever can be seen within minutes of oral intake. Apart from this, the users may have psychiatric symptoms like visual illusions, extreme changes in mood, paranoid delusions, etc. Patients may experience bad trips, where they have panic episodes. Prolonged experience without further exposure to drugs known as “flashbacks" can also result from LSD use. 

Stopping the drug abruptly after continued use does not produce withdrawal symptoms. Management of bad trips due to LSD abuse involves supportive treatment with anxiolytics.

Other named effects of drug use:

  • Amotivational syndrome - Chronic use of cannabis may lead to amotivational syndrome with lethargy and lack of interest in day-to-day activities.
  • Run amok - This is a psychic disturbance resulting from continued use or sudden consumption of Cannabis and is characterized by a peculiar homicidal mania.
  • Magnan syndrome - This is a type of tactile hallucination seen in chronic users of cocaine where they feel as if grains of sand are under the skin or insects are creeping on the skin (formication)

Option A: Cannabis intoxication causes feelings of detachment, euphoria, relaxation, decreased concentration, and attention span. Images appear vivid. There is increased thirst and appetite.

Option B: Amphetamine intoxication also gives rise to similar clinical features like tachycardia, hypertension, sweating, tremors, dilated pupils, and paranoia. However, the scenario mimicking panic attack, makes LSD abuse more likely.

Option C: Cocaine intoxication may also have similar features, like tachycardia, hypertension, sweating, dilated pupils, and altered behaviour. It also causes anesthesia in the area that has been in direct contact with the drug. Magnan syndrome may also be seen.

questions.text: A 5-day-old infant is seen with a rash on his nose, cheek and forehead, as shown in the image below. On examination, they are noted to be pearly opalescent white epidermal inclusion cysts. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Milia is the most probable diagnosis. This condition presents with small cysts formed around the pilosebaceous follicles usually seen over the nose, cheek, and forehead. They are pearly opalescent white epidermal inclusion cysts. 

Infantile milia may occasionally be associated with oral lesions on the gingivae or palate. Milia are more common in white children, but less frequent in children born prematurely or of low gestational weight. They resolve spontaneously without scarring.

 Other options:

Option A: Erythema toxicum presents with papular lesions on an erythematous base with eosinophil laden sterile lesions, distributed over the trunk and face predominantly. It is a normal finding in many newborns. They are seen 1–3 days after birth and may persist for 1 week and resolve spontaneously and do not require any treatment.

Option B: Pustular melanosis is a benign transient condition that lasts for 2-3 days in newborns. It is seen predominantly in black neonates. The lesions are vesiculopustular eruption and have neutrophils.

Option C: Mongolian spots are blue or slate-grey macular lesions, with clearly defined margins, that appear over the presacral region (most common), posterior thighs, legs, back, and forearms.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: A newborn is brought with severe respiratory distress soon after birth. A chest X-ray was done and is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario and the X-ray showing herniation of the bowel loops into the chest is suggestive of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH).

CDH is a structural diaphragmatic defect with or without abdominal contents in the thorax. It allows the abdominal organs to push into the chest cavity resulting in pulmonary hypoplasia and pulmonary hypertension. The most common type of CDH is a bochdalek hernia involving the left side. They may also have a scaphoid abdomen.

Babies with CDH present with respiratory distress immediately after birth characterized by tachypnea, grunting, use of accessory muscles, and cyanosis. Auscultation of the chest may reveal bowel sounds with reduced breath sounds.

Diagnosis is done by a chest radiograph showing herniated bowel loops hemithorax, displacement of the mediastinum to the contralateral side, and reduced lung space. Prenatal diagnosis can be made using ultrasonography between 16 to 24 weeks of gestation.

The immediate step in the management is to place a naso- or orogastric tube for decompression. The airway is to be secured with endotracheal intubation. Bag and mask ventilation should be avoided. Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) and high-frequency oscillatory ventilation have been used as a part of the ventilation strategy.

Bag and mask ventilation should be avoided. Surgical repair of the defect is to be considered at least 48 hours after stabilization and resolution of pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: Structure(s) preserved in case of MRND 1 are:

choices.text: Accessory nerve and internal jugular vein
Accessory nerve, sternocleidomastoid, and internal jugular veins

questions.solution:
Structure preserved in MRND 1 is only the spinal accessory nerve.

There are three types of modified radical neck dissection (MRND). Structures preserved are:

  • MRND 1 - Only spinal accessory nerve 
  • MRND 2 - Accessory nerve and internal jugular vein
  • MRND 3 i.e., functional neck dissection - Accessory nerve, sternocleidomastoid, and internal jugular veins. 

Radical neck dissection involves the removal of:

  • All ipsilateral cervical lymph node groups extending from the inferior border of the mandible to the clavicle and from the lateral border of the sternohyoid muscle, hyoid bone, and contralateral anterior belly of the digastric muscle medially to the anterior border of the trapezius muscle laterally.
  • All lymph nodes from Levels I through to V
  • The spinal accessory nerve
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Sternocleidomastoid muscle
  • Tail of parotid
  • Submandibular gland

A radical neck dissection does not include the removal of the following.

  • sub-occipital nodes
  • peri-parotid nodes (except infraparotid nodes located in the posterior aspect of the submandibular triangle)
  • buccinator nodes
  • retropharyngeal nodes
  • midline visceral (anterior compartment) nodes

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is admitted to the hospital with complains of fever and cough since 4 days. He is oriented to time, place, and person. His respiratory rate is 35/min, BP is 130/90 and serum urea is found to be within normal limits. What is the CURB-65 score in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with a most likely diagnosis of pneumonia has a CURB-65 score of 1 (RR>30/min). The patient can be best managed by a respiratory fluoroquinolone - moxifloxacin in the inpatient Non-ICU category.

The CURB-65 criteria are used to assess the severity of pneumonia. The CURB-65 criteria include five variables (1 point for each variable):

  • Confusion 
  • Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN) >7 mmol/L
  • Respiratory rate ≥30/min 
  • Blood pressure, systolic ≤90 mmHg or diastolic ≤60 mmHg 
  • Age ≥65 years.

Management:

  • 0 point: Treat as an outpatient
  • 1 to 2 points: Admitted to the hospital- Non-ICU
  • ≥3 points: ICU admission

questions.text: This finding in the groin region on Wood's lamp examination is seen in _____
questions.solution:
Coral pink fluorescence in groin region on Wood's Lamp examination is characteristically seen in Erythrasma.

  • Coral pink fluorescence is due to the presence of porphyrins.
  • Corynebacterium minutissimum is the bacterium responsible for erythrasma and conversion of aminolaevulinic acid to protoporphyrin.

questions.text: A 45-year-old alcoholic obese male patient presented to the emergency department with severe pain abdomen radiating to the back. Blood investigations revealed increased serum amylase and lipase levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of the patient is suggestive of acute pancreatitis. 

Acute pancreatitis is a condition characterized by inflammatory damage to the pancreas. Various causes of acute pancreatitis are:

  • Gallstone-induced (most common cause)
  • Alcohol (2nd most common cause)
  • Trauma (most common cause in children)
  • Iatrogenic- Post-endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)
  • Drug-induced pancreatitis (Thiazides, Azathioprine, Anti-cancer drugs, etc)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Scorpion bite
  • Idiopathic

Clinical presentation of acute pancreatitis is characterized by epigastric pain radiating to the back which is relieved by bending forward, nausea, and vomiting. Acute hemorrhagic pancreatitis can present with certain named signs like:

  • Cullen’s sign: Discoloration around the umbilicus
  • Grey Turner’s sign: Discoloration in the flanks
  • Fox sign: Discoloration in the inguinal region
  • Bryant’s sign: Discoloration on the scrotum

Blood investigations show increased serum amylase and lipase levels. Serum lipase is more sensitive and specific than serum amylase but it rises late. USG cannot help establish the diagnosis of pancreatitis. Plain erect chest x-ray and abdominal radiographs are not diagnostic of acute pancreatitis and can only be used to rule out certain differentials. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) is the imaging investigation of choice, but may not always be needed. Various scoring systems are used to grade the severity of acute pancreatitis based on blood investigations and radiographic findings.

questions.text: How often should health check-ups be conducted for children aged 9-18 years under the RBSK program?
questions.solution:
According to the Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) program, health check-ups for children aged 9-18 years should occur semi-annually.

This frequency allows healthcare providers to comprehensively assess various aspects of the child's health, including physical, mental, and emotional well-being. Semi-annual check-ups enable early detection of any emerging health issues, facilitate timely interventions, and ensure continuity of care. This proactive approach helps promote overall health and contributes to improved health outcomes among children. 

Option (a): Monthly health check-ups may be overly frequent and impractical, potentially burdening healthcare resources unnecessarily.

Option (c): Quarterly assessments may not be necessary for children in this age group unless specific health concerns arise. Semi-annual check-ups strike a balance between monitoring and avoiding excessive medicalization.

Option (d): Annual check-ups may not suffice to monitor the dynamic health needs of children aged 9-18 years adequately.

questions.text: A young female presented with the following findings on the face. Which among the following will not be useful for its treatment?
questions.solution:
The age of the patient and the presence of papules and pustules with an erythematous base on the face are suggestive of acne. All the above agents are useful in the treatment of acne except topical fluocinolone (topical steroid). Corticosteroids may provoke an acneform reaction irrespective of their route of administration.

Acne is a chronic inflammatory disease of the pilosebaceous unit. It is commonly seen in teenagers. It can vary from very mild comedonal acne to severe aggressive pustular acne. These eventually may lead to scarring due to sinus formation.

Acne results from the combination of:

  • Increased sebaceous gland activity under the influence of androgens - oily skin
  • Abnormal follicular differentiation with increased keratinization- hypercornification of the duct due to increased IL-1
  • Microbial hypercolonization of the follicular canal leading to its inflammation.

Management-

  • Mild comedonal acne is treated with a topical retinoid. Mild papular and pustular acne is treated with topical retinoid and topical antibiotics.
  • Moderate papular/pustular acne and moderate nodular acne are treated with oral antibiotic + topical retinoid with or without benzoyl peroxide. 
  • Severe nodular and conglobate acne are treated with oral isotretinoin.

Tazarotene is a fourth‐generation retinoid, which is available for the treatment of acne.

questions.text: Which of the following radioisotopes is used in a PET-CT scan?
questions.solution:
18F-FDG is the radioisotope used in a PET-CT scan.

Positron emission tomography - CT (PET-CT):

  • PET imaging is based on the detection of an injected positron-emitting radioactive tracer.
  • It relies on the coincidence detection of the annihilation photons (γ), which are released when a positron combines with an electron.
  • A glucose analogue called FDG (fluorodeoxyglucose) is used in PET imaging. FDG is taken up by metabolically active cells, where it undergoes phosphorylation to form FDG-6-phosphate. Unlike glucose, FDG-6-phosphate cannot undergo further metabolism and becomes trapped within the cell. (So, the patient must be fasted for 4-6 hrs prior to imaging).
  • The trapped FDG-6-phosphate is detected by the PET scanner. 
  • Before injecting FDG, the blood glucose level should be measured. It should be < 150 mg/dL. Good blood glucose control is essential as FDG uptake is competitively inhibited by glucose.
  • Imaging is started 60 minutes following FDG injection.

Indications of PET-CT:

  • PET-CT is used in oncology imaging to detect malignant cells as they demonstrate increased glucose metabolism relative to normal tissues.
  • It is indicated for the differentiation of a malignant from a benign lesion.
  • It is indicated in tumour staging and evaluation of tumour recurrence.

Areas of normal physiological uptake in PET CT:

  • Brain tissue
  • Skeletal muscle, especially after strenuous activity, and laryngeal muscles following speech
  • Myocardium
  • Gastrointestinal tract, e.g. intestinal wall
  • Genitourinary tract (FDG is excreted via the renal system and passes into the collecting systems)
  • Brown fat (FDG accumulates here as glucose and ATP are required for heat production)
  • Thymus
  • Bone marrow

Other options:

Option A: 16F-FDG (Fluorodeoxyglucose) is a radiolabeled glucose analogue used in Positron Emission Tomography (PET) to assess metabolic activity in tissues. It is particularly useful for detecting cancer, and infections, and monitoring neurological disorders due to its ability to highlight areas with high glucose consumption.

Option C: Carbon-11 (C-11) is used for certain types of PET imaging, particularly in neurology and oncology.

Option D: Gallium-68 (Ga-68) is used for imaging certain types of neuroendocrine tumours and somatostatin receptor imaging.
