questions.text: A young male who had a road traffic accident is brought to the emergency department. His left leg is shortened, internally rotated, and adducted. On examination, femoral artery pulsation is not felt. A plain radiograph of his hip was taken which is shown below. What is your diagnosis?

choices.text: Fracture neck of femur with injury to femoral vessels
Anterior dislocation of hip with femoral artery injury

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of posterior hip dislocation. In this condition, the leg will be in flexion, adduction, and internal rotation. 

Posterior hip dislocation is the commonest type of hip dislocation accounting for about 80%  of the cases. It is commonly seen following dashboard injuries. The patient presents with flexion, adduction, and an internal rotation deformity.

Radiological findings include femoral head lying above and behind the acetabulum, femoral head appearing smaller than normal, lesser trochanter not visualized as the thigh is internally rotated and the femoral head and posterior acetabular wall fractures may also be seen

Sciatic nerve injury is seen in 10-20 % of cases with posterior hip dislocation. It is usually a neuropraxia type of injury and resolves spontaneously. The femoral artery pulsation is usually felt against the neck of the femur. Due to the posterior dislocation of the hip joint, the femoral vessels fall backwards and the pulsation of the femoral artery cannot be felt. This is called the vascular sign of Narath.

Anterior hip dislocation is less common than posterior hip dislocations and accounts for about 10-20% of all hip dislocations. This injury is usually sustained following a high-energy accident. The affected limb in this condition will be abducted, externally rotated, and slightly flexed.

Note: Although, vascular injuries are seen in posterior dislocations as well, they are most likely with anterior dislocation. This is because of the femoral artery lying anterior to the head

questions.text: What is the standard glucose load given for identifying diabetes in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
For IADPSG criteria, an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) is done in the fasting state using 75 g of glucose, and gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) is diagnosed if any one of the following cut-offs is met i.e.

  • Fasting: >92 mg/dl 
  • 1 hour: >180 mg/dl  
  • 2 hour: >153 mg/dl

Earlier, a two-step approach was being used to diagnose GDM. In this, the first step (screening) is a 50-gram one-hour glucose challenge test (GCT). The patients having a positive result of >140mg/dl, are candidates for the OGTT. A 100-gram, three-hour oral glucose tolerance test (GTT), is the diagnostic test for gestational diabetes mellitus. GDM is diagnosed if two or more values are positive.

Diabetes in Pregnancy Societies of India(DIPSI) recommends a 1-step procedure with 75 g oral glucose without regard to the time of the last meal. A venous plasma glucose value at 2 hours >140 mg/dL is diagnosed as GDM.

Some complications of GDM include:

  • Maternal
    • Hypertension, preeclampsia
    • Hydramnios
    • Increased operative interventions
    • Future development of diabetes mellitus
  • Fetal and neonatal
    • Fetal macrosomia
    • Congenital anomalies
    • Metabolic abnormalities such as hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia, hyperbilirubinemia, and neonatal hypoglycemia.
    • Respiratory distress syndrome
    • Subsequent childhood and adolescent obesity

 

Screening is usually done at 24-28 weeks of gestation. Early diagnosis and treatment are important to prevent complications.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female was raped two years back. Who has the authority to impose a death sentence on the convicted accused?
questions.solution:
Sessions court can pass a death sentence but it has to be confirmed by the high court.

It is the highest judicial tribunal for the district and is located in the district headquarters. The court is presided over by the Sessions Judge, appointed by the High Court. High Court may also appoint Additional Sessions Judges and Assistant Sessions Judges to exercise jurisdiction in the court of sessions.

It takes up only the cases of criminal offences referred by Magistrate’s courts.

Magistrate’s courts are criminal courts presided over by the Judicial/ Metropolitan Magistrates. In every district, the State Government after consultation with the High Court may establish as many Courts of Judicial Magistrate as it may consider necessary. Judicial judges can pass a sentence of imprisonment for 7 years only and cannot pass a death sentence.

District Court primarily handles civil litigation matters.

Assistant Sessions Court has the jurisdiction to issue prison sentences of up to ten years along with imposing unlimited fines.

questions.text: In an elderly male experiencing recurrent fainting episodes, the electrocardiogram shows P waves at a rate of 75 beats per minute and qRS complexes at a rate of 35 bpm. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this clinical scenario, elderly male experiencing recurrent fainting episodes, with P waves at 75 bpm and qRS complexes at 35 bpm.

The presence of P waves at a rate of 75 bpm suggests normal atrial activity, while qRS complexes at a rate of 35 bpm indicate a significant bradycardia. This combination of findings is consistent with a severe AV block, suggesting a diagnosis of Stokes-Adams syndrome.

Stokes-Adams syndrome, also known as Adams-Stokes syndrome, refers to episodes of syncope (fainting) caused by sudden, temporary interruptions of the heart's electrical activity, leading to a lack of blood flow to the brain. This interruption often results from complete heart block (third-degree AV block) or other severe bradyarrhythmias.

Prompt recognition and management, including consideration of pacemaker therapy, are essential in such cases to prevent further syncopal episodes and potential complications.

Other options:

OPTION B: (Second-degree AV block: Second-degree AV block is characterized by intermittent failure of atrial impulses to conduct to the ventricles. This condition may present with a variety of patterns, such as Mobitz type I (Wenckebach) or Mobitz type II. While second-degree AV block can lead to symptomatic bradycardia and syncope, the specific ECG findings described in the question are more consistent with a complete heart block or severe bradycardia.

OPTION C: First-degree AV block: First-degree AV block is characterized by a prolonged PR interval on the ECG, indicating delayed conduction from the atria to the ventricles. It typically does not result in symptomatic bradycardia or syncope.

OPTION D: Electrical alternans: Electrical alternans refer to a phenomenon in which the amplitude of certain ECG waves, such as the QRS complex or T wave, alternates from beat to beat. It is often associated with pericardial effusion, cardiac tamponade, or severe left ventricular dysfunction, rather than bradyarrhythmias leading to syncope.

questions.text: Following a road traffic accident, a 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department with maxillofacial trauma and inability to open the mouth. To establish an airway, an emergency laryngotomy is performed. Where is the opening made?
questions.solution:
In laryngotomy, an opening is made on the cricothyroid membrane.

Laryngotomy is also called cricothyrotomy or mini-tracheostomy. It is done as an emergency life-saving procedure to buy some time to allow a patient to be carried to the operation theatre. Once stable, it is replaced by intubation or tracheostomy.

Most of the laryngeal foreign bodies are arrested above the vocal cords, i.e. above the middle of the thyroid cartilage. Thus, an effective airway can be provided by piercing the cricothyroid membrane.

questions.text: What is the most commonly affected organ in an air blast due to shockwave?
questions.solution:
Lungs are considered to be severely damaged organs in the air due to variations in density between the alveolar walls and the contained air.

A blast causes the most damage at an interface between tissues in contact with the atmosphere, which is why the lung usually suffers the most severe damage.

Blast injury is a complex type of physical trauma resulting from direct or indirect exposure to an explosion. Primary blast injuries result from the rapid overpressure or shock waves produced by an explosion. These injuries result from the dramatic changes in barometric pressure projecting outwards from the point of detonation. They predominantly cause damage to air-filled hollow organs of the body from rapid pressure change (barotrauma). This includes the middle ear, lungs, and GIT.

The most sensitive and most frequently injured hollow organs are the tympanic membranes > lungs.

Blast damage to the lungs is the most common cause of life-threatening injury following an explosion.

Solid organs are the most resistant to blast injuries as the parenchymal disruption requires very high levels of overpressure. The liver is the least vulnerable to blast wave (primary blast) injury.

questions.text: A woman underwent  surgery for a fracture of the femur shaft. She has been on a cast for a month. Since yesterday, she developed sudden onset of breathlessness and chest pain. Her chest examination is normal. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of immobilization after the application of the cast is a risk factor for Deep Vein Thrombosis, which might have led to a pulmonary embolism.

Pulmonary embolism refers to embolic occlusion of the pulmonary arterial system. It is the commonest complication of deep vein thrombosis leading to death. Larger emboli wedge in the main pulmonary artery causing a wedge-shaped infarct, while smaller emboli occlude the peripheral arteries.

Most patients present with pleuritic chest pain, dyspnoea, and tachypnoea. The classical clinical triad of sudden onset of chest pain, dyspnoea, and hemoptysis is present in only a few cases.

Risk factors for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) include Postoperative thrombosis: (Most common cause), childbirth, Immobility – Bed-ridden, long-duration air or bus travel (Traveller’s thrombosis), pregnancy, puerperium, oral contraceptives.

It occurs commonly in the pelvic veins and leg veins-femoral and popliteal veins.

Patients present with fever, tenderness, warmth and pale swollen calf. Homan’s, Mose’s or Neuhof’s signs and inverted champagne bottle sign can be seen on examination.

Pneumothorax presents with sudden onset breathlessness but has reduced breath sounds and hyper resonant on percussion. This patient has a normal chest examination.

  • It is also called a bar graph.

  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: A woman is suspected to have endometriosis. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
For endometriosis, the investigation of choice which can help with both the diagnosis and treatment is laparoscopy. It is used to locate the sites, take a biopsy and surgically remove the deposits.

Endometriosis is the presence of endometrium at a site outside the uterine cavity. It can be found in ectopic sites such as the ovary, pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligaments, appendix, pelvic lymph nodes, lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) scar endometriosis, umbilicus, and lung.

Dysmenorrhea is the most common presenting symptom, associated with abdominal and pelvic pain, menorrhagia, dyspareunia and infertility. Laparoscopy is the gold standard modality for the diagnosis and treatment of endometriosis. Typical characteristics include 'powder-burn' - puckered black spots, red vascular, bluish, blackish cysts, chocolate cysts, and dense adhesions in the pelvis.

For minimal disease, medical management with NSAIDs and oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are given if associated menstrual complaints are present. OCPs inhibit gonadotropin release and decrease the menstrual flow. For moderate to severe diseases oral progestogens, GnRH agonists or danazol that antagonize estrogenic effects on the endometrium, causing endometrial atrophy are used.

Surgery is preferred in patients with infertility. Endometrial deposits are destroyed by electrocautery/laser, and resection of endometrioma can be done. Total hysterectomy with bilateral oophorectomy is a definitive and most effective therapy for women with endometriosis who do not wish to retain fertility.

questions.text: A 25  year old male has thoughts of cutting his fingers, he plans and imagines doing it but never actually does it. He says that his sister is influencing his thoughts. His mother reports that he has no sister, and he talks to someone who is not present in the room. Which of the following is the cause?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, the patient is suffering from thought insertion. Thought insertion is seen in schizophrenia. The delusion of thoughts being placed into patient’s mind by someone else.

The first rank symptoms of schizophrenia described by Kurt Schneider include :

1. Hallucination:

Audible thoughts - auditory hallucinations of a person’s voice being spoken aloud.
Voices arguing or discussing - auditory hallucinations of two or more voices arguing or discussing, usually about the person experiencing the hallucination.

Voices commenting on the patient’s actions - auditory hallucinations commenting on a person’s behavior or actions.

2. Thought Phenomenon : 

  • Thought withdrawal -  thoughts being actively removed from a person’s mind.
  • Thought insertion - thoughts inserted into a person’s mind by some external agent.
  • Thought broadcasting - the sense that a person’s thoughts are experienced by others - the thoughts are made audible or may be experienced by others through telepathy.

3. Made Phenomenon:

  • Made affect - feelings are imposed on that person by an external agent.
  • Made impulses or drives - an impulse for action is imposed on a person by some external agent.
  • Made volitional acts - a person’s actions are controlled by an external agent; the person is a passive participant in the action.

4. Delusional perception - the person attaches an abnormal significance/meaning to a normal perception, which leads to delusional interpretation.

5. Somatic passivity - tactile or visceral hallucinations that are thought to be imposed on a person's body by some external agent. These symptoms are not specific for schizophrenia and may also be present in other psychiatric disorders.

Other options:

Option A: Forced thinking is usually seen in patients with frontal lobe epilepsy.The thoughts are formed are not in the control of the patient and are distressing thoughts.

Option C: Crowding of thoughts is also seen in schizophrenia. The patient has thoughts that are too fast and excessive and unexplainable. The patient can even locate these thoughts crowding at the back of the head.

Option D: The obsessive-compulsive symptoms are not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medi­cation) or another medical condition.The patient feels the need to carry out certain behaviours to get rid of these thoughts.

questions.text: Which of these steps is followed first for the management of shoulder dystocia after McRoberts maneuver?

questions.solution:
Applying a gentle suprapubic pressure is the first step in the management of shoulder dystocia after the McRoberts maneuver.

  • Woods screw maneuver is applied.
  • Rubin maneuver is attempted.

Other techniques generally should be reserved for cases in which all other maneuvers have failed. These include intentional fracture of the anterior clavicle and the Zavanelli maneuver.

questions.text: In which type of poisoning will there be increased secretion along with diarrhea?
questions.solution:
Increased secretion along with diarrhea can be seen in ketamine poisoning.

Ketamine is a phencyclidine derivative that inhibits NMDA (N-methyl-D-aspartate) receptors resulting in a decrease in excitatory stimulation by glutamate in the brain. It is a strong analgesic and amnestic agent. 

Uses:

  • Ketamine is the intravenous agent of choice for patients with shock, low cardiac output states, and reactive airway diseases.
  • It is also used in patients with congenital heart diseases, especially with right-to-left shunts
  • Perioperative analgesia

Other adverse effects:

  • Hallucination is the most common side effect of ketamine.
  • Emergence reaction (vivid dreaming, illusion, etc)
  • Increased salivation, nausea, vomiting
  • Increases brain oxygen consumption and metabolic rate leading to increased intracranial tension.

Other options:

Cannabis: Large doses of cannabis causes nausea, anxiety, confusion, hallucinations and delusions. This is followed by giddiness, confusion, drowsiness and dilated pupils. 

Cocaine: Acute intoxication mainly causes euphoria, hypervigilance, agitation, tactile hallucination, and finally respiratory failure or cardiac arrest.

Crack: This is obtained by heating the cocaine with sodium bicarbonate to yield a hard white mass. This material gives off a cracking sound when smoked and hence the name.

questions.text: A 45-year-old alcoholic obese male patient presented to the emergency department with severe pain abdomen radiating to the back. Blood investigations revealed increased serum amylase and lipase levels. Which of the following should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of the patient is suggestive of acute pancreatitis. And 5% dextrose should be avoided in this condition.

Acute pancreatitis is a condition characterized by inflammatory damage to the pancreas. Various causes of acute pancreatitis are:

  • Gallstone-induced (most common cause)
  • Alcohol (2nd most common cause)
  • Trauma (most common cause in children)
  • Iatrogenic- Post-endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)
  • Drug-induced pancreatitis (Thiazides, Azathioprine, Anti-cancer drugs, etc)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Scorpion bite
  • Idiopathic

Clinical presentation of acute pancreatitis is characterized by epigastric pain radiating to the back which is relieved by bending forward, nausea, and vomiting. Acute hemorrhagic pancreatitis can present with certain named signs like:

  • Cullen’s sign: Discoloration around the umbilicus
  • Grey Turner’s sign: Discoloration in the flanks
  • Fox sign: Discoloration in the inguinal region
  • Bryant’s sign: Discoloration on the scrotum

Blood investigations show increased serum amylase and lipase levels. Serum lipase is more sensitive and specific than serum amylase but it rises late. USG cannot help establish the diagnosis of pancreatitis. Plain erect chest x-ray and abdominal radiographs are not diagnostic of acute pancreatitis and can only be used to rule out certain differentials. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) is the imaging investigation of choice, but may not always be needed. Various scoring systems are used to grade the severity of acute pancreatitis based on blood investigations and radiographic findings.

Management:

In the management of acute pancreatitis, it's crucial to avoid stimulating the pancreas further, as it can exacerbate inflammation and worsen symptoms. Therefore, solutions containing glucose, such as 5% dextrose, should be avoided because they can trigger pancreatic enzyme secretion.

5% Dextrose is also a hypotonic solution and cannot maintain plasma oncotic pressure and will exaggerate the underlying third space loss.

Instead, fluids should be administered intravenously as necessary, but they should be non-stimulating to the pancreas, such as normal saline or lactated Ringer's solution.

Early initiation of oral feedings is also not recommended in the acute phase of pancreatitis because it can lead to increased pancreatic stimulation and exacerbation of symptoms. Oral intake should be avoided until the patient's condition improves and pancreatic enzyme levels normalize.

Parenteral nutrition may be considered in severe cases of acute pancreatitis or when oral intake cannot be resumed within a few days. However, it is not universally preferred for all patients, and the decision to initiate parenteral nutrition should be based on the patient's clinical status, nutritional needs, and response to other management strategies.

questions.text: A  patient was brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. His CT scan is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given CT image shows a crescent-shaped lesion that crosses suture lines and is indicative of acute subdural hematoma/hemorrhage.

Subdural hemorrhage (SDH) is a collection of blood between the dura and the arachnoid layers of the meninges. Most commonly, it results from the rupture of cortical bridging veins. Non-contrast CT is the investigation of choice.

Radiographic features of subdural hemorrhages:

  • Crescent-like distribution around the periphery of the brain.
  • They are not limited by sutures.
  • Crescent-shaped hypodense lesion on axial CT: Chronic subdural hemorrhage
  • Crescent-shaped hyperdense collections on CT: Acute subdural hemorrhage.

questions.text: A male patient comes with acute chest pain for the past one hour. ECG shows ST segment elevation in the leads II, III and aVF. What is the most appropriate intervention?
questions.solution:
The patient given in the scenario with sudden onset chest pain and ST elevation in leads II, III, and aVF is suggestive of inferior wall MI and the most appropriate intervention is primary angioplasty. This intervention aims to restore blood flow to the affected coronary artery promptly and is associated with improved outcomes in acute STEMI compared to fibrinolytic therapy when performed.

Inferior wall MI mainly occurs due to blockage of the posterior descending branch of the right coronary artery. While anterior wall infarction shows sympathetic nervous system hyperactivity (tachycardia and hypertension), the inferior wall MI shows parasympathetic hyperactivity (bradycardia and hypotension).

Morphine and nitrates are contraindicated in an inferior wall MI due to the risk of further impairing the right ventricular preload.

Beta blockers (Option D) are generally not recommended either, due to the risk of the MI involving the AV node. Beta blockers can block the AV node which can lead to further AV blocks. 

Other options:

Option B: Dabigatran is an anticoagulant medication commonly used for the prevention of stroke and systemic embolism in patients with atrial fibrillation and for the treatment and prevention of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. However, it is not indicated as the initial treatment for acute ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).

Option C: Streptokinase is another fibrinolytic agent used for thrombolysis in the treatment of acute myocardial infarction, acute ischemic stroke, and acute pulmonary embolism. It is considered only an alternative reperfusion strategy in acute STEMI when primary angioplasty is unavailable or contraindicated.

The following protocol must be followed in the management of patients with acute coronary syndrome:

  1. Stabilization of airway, breathing and circulation.
  2. Administration of O2
  3. Give aspirin 325 mg and clopidogrel
  4. History and examination, assess cardiac biomarkers.
  5. Give up to three sublingual nitroglycerin tablets each 5 min apart till the pain subsides. Add IV nitroglycerin for the persistence of symptoms.
  6. Treat left heart failure if present with an after-load reducing agent or loop diuretic.
  7. Give beta blockers if there are no features of heart failure.
  8. Give morphine for the persistence of anxiety and discomfort related to MI.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old woman presents with acute onset abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. She has a low-grade fever, with a pulse rate of 90 bpm and blood pressure of 126/84 mm Hg. She has regular menstrual cycles of 28 days. Pelvic examination shows a tender right adnexal mass. Ovarian torsion is suspected. What is the investigation of choice in this condition?

Urine pregnancy testing- negative
Serum β-HCG level- 1 mIU/L
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of ovarian torsion. The investigation of choice for an ovarian torsion is a doppler sonography.

Torsion of the ovaries is a gynecological emergency and is most commonly seen in women of the reproductive age group. Ovarian cysts including mucous cystadenomas and dermoid cysts have the highest risks of undergoing torsion. Adnexal masses measuring >6 cm in diameter have the highest rates of torsion.

A patient with torsion presents with sharp lower abdominal pain, usually localized to the involved side with radiation to the flank, groin, or thigh. Nausea and vomiting are commonly associated. Adnexal necrosis may cause a low-grade fever. 

During torsion, the low-pressure veins are initially compressed by the twisting pedicle. This leads to continuous inflow with decreased outflow causing stromal edema and congestion. The increasing stromal swelling later compresses the arteries causing ischemia and necrosis.

On a doppler USG, the ovary appears enlarged, globular, and has a heterogenous appearance compared to the contralateral ovary due to edema, engorgement, and hemorrhage. Twisting of the vascular pedicle may give rise to a 'whirlpool sign', a round hyperechoic structure with concentric hypoechoic stripes. MRI or CT imaging can be used in patients with normal Doppler but with characteristic signs and symptoms of torsion, to confirm or rule out the diagnosis.

Management involves urgent laparotomy or laparoscopic evaluation. Salvage of the involved adnexa with the removal of any associated cyst/tumor and possible oophoropexy are the goals. However, necrosis of the adnexa necessitates the removal of the adnexal structures.

questions.text: A patient comes to you with a history of unprotected sex  96 hours ago. Which of the following emergency contraceptives can be used in this case?
questions.solution:
Since the patient had unprotected sex 96 hours ago, an intrauterine contraceptive device(IUCD) can be used for emergency contraception in this case. It can be inserted within 5 days of coitus as a method of emergency contraception. All other methods of emergency contraception mentioned above need to be administered within 72 hours.

The administration of postcoital contraceptive agents that interfere with postovulatory events that can lead to pregnancy is known as the emergency contraception method. They are used to prevent pregnancy after unprotected intercourse.

IUCD (Intrauterine contraceptive device) prevents the implantation of a fertilized ovum. It does so by acting as a foreign body within the uterine cavity. This leads to increased contractility, tubal peristalsis, and promotes leukocytic infiltration in the endometrium so that the fertilized egg is unable to implant.

questions.text:
Arrange the sequence of lactation in the right order
  1. Mammogenesis
  2. Lactogenesis
  3. Galactokinesis
  4. Galactopoiesis
questions.solution:
The correct order of lactation is: Mammogenesis – lactogenesis – galactokinesis – galactopoiesis

Function Definition Hormone
Mammogenesis Breast growth and development

Estrogen (ductal growth)

Progesterone (alveolar growth)
Lactogenesis Initiation of milk secretion Prolactin
Galactokinesis Ejection of milk Oxytocin
Galactopoiesis Maintainence of lactation Prolactin

Mammogenesis: This refers to the development and growth of the mammary glands. It occurs during puberty and pregnancy under the influence of hormones like estrogen and progesterone.

Lactogenesis: This is the process of milk production. There are two phases:

  • a. Lactogenesis I: Also known as colostrum secretion, it begins during late pregnancy and continues after birth for a few days. The mammary glands produce colostrum, a thick, yellowish fluid rich in antibodies and nutrients.
  • b. Lactogenesis II: Also known as transitional milk secretion, it begins around 2-5 days after birth. The mammary glands switch to producing mature milk.

Galactokinesis: This involves the movement of milk through the mammary ducts towards the nipple. It is facilitated by the contraction of myoepithelial cells surrounding the alveoli in response to oxytocin release.

Galactopoiesis: This refers to the maintenance and regulation of milk production. It involves hormonal regulation, primarily prolactin, which stimulates milk synthesis and secretion. Additionally, factors like frequent breastfeeding or milk removal help maintain milk production.

So, the correct sequence is Mammogenesis (development of mammary glands) – Lactogenesis (milk production) – Galactokinesis (movement of milk) – Galactopoiesis (maintenance of milk production.

The American Heart Association recommends collecting three sets of blood culture samples for patients with suspected infective endocarditis. One set should be collected from the affected valve, if possible. The other two sets should be collected from peripheral veins. Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with breast carcinoma develops right upper limb lymphedema after mastectomy as a result of axillary lymph node dissection. 10 years later, she presents with multiple confluent, hemorrhagic, necrotic, and elevated purple-black papules over the right upper limb. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this setting is lymphangiosarcoma.

Angiosarcoma can arise in the setting of lymphedema, classically in the ipsilateral upper extremity, several years after radical mastectomy with lymph node resection for breast cancer known as Stewart–Treves syndrome (STS). The tumor presumably arises from lymphatic vessels (lymphangiosarcoma).

questions.text: The hormone acting on post ovulatory endometrium is :
questions.solution:
The hormone acting on the post ovulatory endometrium is progesterone.

In the post ovulatory period, there is an immediate rise in progesterone levels, secreted by the developing corpus luteum.This phase is called the luteal phase where the vascularity and secretory activity of the endometrium increase to prepare for receipt of a fertilized egg. Oestrogen levels also increase, however the rise is seen only from the mid-luteal phase.

If fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum regresses at the end of the luteal phase. As a result, oestrogen and progesterone levels decrease abruptly. This prompts the shedding of the  superficial layer (decidua functionalis) of the endometrium.

The normal menstrual cycle consists of the following phases :

  1. Menstruation (0 - 4 days)
  2. Follicular phase (10 -14 days)
  3. Ovulation (14th day)
  4. Luteal phase (14 - 28)

Related Pearl: Hormonal Regulation of Menstrual Cycle

questions.text: A pre-menopausal woman is diagnosed with lymph node-positive, early invasive breast cancer. IHC reveals ER +, PR +, and HER-2-neu 1+. Which of the following drug will you provide for this patient?

The given clinical scenario suggests early invasive breast cancer in a pre-menopausal woman, which is lymph node-positive, hormone receptor-positive (ER/PR +), and Her-2/neu negative (Her-2/neu IHC score of 1+ is considered negative). Hence Tamoxifen is the drug of choice. 

Treatment of early-stage breast cancer (T1-2 N0-1 M0) includes:

Breast conservation surgery (BCS) + ALND or SLNB + Radiotherapy
  • BCS is followed by radiotherapy
  • Mastectomy is done if BCS is contraindicated.
  • Clinical N0 status-sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) at the time of surgery.
  • Clinical N1 status-ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration (FNA): axillary lymph node dissection (ALND) if positive and sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) if negative.
Endocrine therapy: for hormone receptor (ER/PR) positive 
  • For Premenopausal women-tamoxifen (selective estrogen receptor modulator, SERM)
  • For post-menopausal women (usually >50 years)-anastrozole (Aromatase inhibitor)
  • Tamoxifen has an agonistic action on the endometrium, leading to an increased risk of endometrial cancers Hence, it is not used in post-menopausal women.

Anti-Her-2 therapy: for Her-2/neu positive breast cancer
  • Trastuzumab is given
  • Her-2/neu IHC interpretation:
  •   0 or 1+ = Negative
  •   2+ = Equivocal cases ->        confirmed with Fluorescence    in situ hybridization (FISH)      analysis
  •   3+ = Positive
Chemotherapy

Indicated for:

  • Lymph nodes positive
  • Lymph nodes negative but tumor size of >1 cm
  • Lymph nodes negative and tumor size of >0.5 cm with
    • Blood vessel/Lymph vessel invasion
    • ER/PR –ve

    • High grade
  • Triple-negative breast carcinoma
  • High recurrence score after Oncotype Dx

questions.text: A woman with mitral stenosis experiences sudden-onset respiratory difficulty, limb oedema, and abdominal distension. What is the likely clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely clinical diagnosis for the woman with mitral stenosis experiencing sudden-onset respiratory difficulty, limb edema, and abdominal distension is pulmonary edema. This is consistent with the pathophysiology of mitral stenosis leading to left atrial hypertension and subsequent pulmonary congestion, resulting in the clinical features described.

Pulmonary edema is the accumulation of fluid in the lung tissue and air spaces. In the context of mitral stenosis, pulmonary edema can occur due to left atrial hypertension and subsequent increased hydrostatic pressure in the pulmonary circulation. This can lead to sudden-onset respiratory difficulty (dyspnea), orthopnea (difficulty breathing while lying flat), paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (sudden awakening with difficulty breathing), limb edema, and possibly coughing up frothy sputum. Therefore, pulmonary edema is the likely clinical diagnosis in this scenario.

Other options:

  • Pulmonary embolism occurs when a blood clot (embolus) travels to the lungs, obstructing blood flow in the pulmonary arteries. While pulmonary embolism can cause respiratory difficulty, it typically presents with acute pleuritic chest pain, hemoptysis (coughing up blood), and signs of right heart strain on physical examination. Limb edema and abdominal distension are less commonly associated with pulmonary embolism.
  • Cerebral embolism refers to the occlusion of a cerebral artery by an embolus, leading to ischemic stroke. While patients with mitral stenosis are at risk for systemic embolization, presenting as stroke-like symptoms such as focal neurological deficits, sudden-onset respiratory difficulty.
  • Paradoxical embolism occurs when a blood clot from the venous circulation crosses into the arterial circulation through a cardiac defect, such as a patent foramen ovale, causing systemic embolization.

Precipitin test is an antigen-antibody reaction test used to distinguish between species (human or animal). It is done to confirm if the stain is of human origin.

questions.text: An elderly male with a history of chronic smoking is diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the lower lip stage. Further investigations revealed that the lymph nodes are not involved. What is the treatment of choice in this patient?

choices.text: Wide local excision with negative margins
Wide local excision with frozen borders

questions.solution:
This pateint has an early stage squamous cell carcinoma. Wide local excision with negative margins is the preferred treatment for this type of cancer.

Lip cancer most commonly occurs in men from 50 to 70 years but can be seen in younger patients. Risk factors include sunlight exposure, smoking, and tobacco use. Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of lip cancer. But commonly occurring cancer in the upper lip is basal cell carcinoma.

Surgical resection (wide local excision with negative margins) is the preferred treatment modality. The typical lip length is 6 to 7 cm. For defects of <1/3rd of the lip, resection with primary closure is the preferred treatment.

For defects of more than 1/3rd of the lip, require local flaps for reconstruction after resection:

  • Johansen step technique- local flap for large central defects 
  • Lip-switch (Abbe-Estlander) flap- based on the sublabial or superior labial artery. When the defect involves only the commissure, the Estlander flap is used, and the Abbé flap is used for midline defects. Abbe-Estlander Flap is used for mixed defects. The markings of the Abbe-Estlander flap are shown below.
  • Karapandzic flap - circumoral advancement flap. It is a neuromuscular flap that includes the remaining orbicularis oris muscle with its innervation.

In the presence of neck metastasis, neck dissection is indicated. Postoperative radiation is administered to patients with positive margins, lymph node metastases, tumor thickness >4mm, or perineural invasion. If the mandible is involved, mandibulectomy and free flap reconstruction is required.

questions.text: A patient presents with elbow deformity and forearm shortening after a fall. An X-ray was done and given below.  What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and X-ray are suggestive of elbow dislocation. X-ray shows posterior dislocation of the elbow joint. 

Elbow dislocation is the most common dislocation in the pediatric age group and the second most common dislocation after the shoulder in adults.

Posterior dislocation is the commonest type of elbow dislocation. It frequently occurs due to a fall on the outstretched hands with the elbow slightly flexed. Other dislocations are postero-medial, postero-lateral, and divergent.

Anterior dislocation occurs when the elbow is flexed and there is a direct blow on the posterior aspect of the elbow joint.

Clinical features:

  • The forearm appears shortened.
  • Crepitus is absent.
  • The three-point bony relationship is disrupted.
  • Olecranon is above the intercondylar line

Elbow dislocation is an emergency and has to be reduced immediately. Closed reduction under general anaesthesia(GA) is attempted first. An above elbow POP slab is applied with 90º elbow flexion and mid-pronation for a period of 3 weeks after closed reduction under GA.

Stimson’s 2 step principles for closed reduction

  1. Step 1 - traction along the long axis of the humerus to counteract the contraction of biceps, triceps and brachialis
  2. Step 2 - traction along the long axis of the forearm to bring radius and ulna back into position
    2 techniques in closed reduction

Prone technique - Grab the wrist of the injured arm. Apply traction and slight supination to the forearm. Using the other hand, apply pressure to the posterior aspect of the olecranon while the arm is pronated.

Supine technique - a helper stabilizes the humerus against the stretcher with both hands. Grasp the wrist, and apply slow, steady, inline traction, keeping the elbow slightly flexed and the wrist supinated

Complications:

  • Early complications include neurovascular injury. Vascular injuries are rare and involve the brachial artery in open fractures associated with elbow dislocation.
  • Late complications include myositis ossificans, recurrent dislocations, proximal radioulnar translocation, and ectopic calcifications

questions.text: A 49-year-old man presented to the OPD with complaints of a gradually progressive swelling over his abdomen for 1.5 years. He has a history of penetrating stab injury at the same site. On examination, the swelling was >12 cm and was partially reducible with a palpable cough impulse. Which of the following is the best way to manage this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Incisional hernias are repaired by fascial closure augmented with a mesh. 
 
Incisional hernia refers to an abdominal wall hernia at the site of a previous surgical incision. It is a type of ventral hernia. Incisional hernias are usually asymptomatic, but can occasionally present with pain. Strangulation and bowel obstruction is rare due to the large neck of the defect. In general, incisional hernias are repaired by fascial closure augmented with a mesh. There are different options for mesh placement:
  • Onlay (above the anterior fascia, over the defect)
  • Inlay (between the fascial edges without overlap)
  • Sublay (below the fascial components) - this includes retrorectus, preperitoneal, and intraperitoneal (IPOM) mesh placements 

Primary suture repair using Mayo’s technique is reserved only for very small hernias with < 2cm defect. This involves closing the fascial edges with a 2 cm overlap using an interrupted suture and then reinforcing it with a continuous running suture (double-breasting).

questions.text: What is the best method to preserve a blood-stained handkerchief recovered from a crime scene?

choices.text: Dry over spirit lamp and preserve it
Stained area folded and preserved in plastic bag
Rinse with water to prevent contamination
Stained area folded and preserved in paper bag

questions.solution:
The stained handkerchief should be folded and preserved in a paper bag.

Preservation of Blood stains:

  • The stained item should be allowed to air dry at room temperature without applying additional heat, as heat can degrade the stain.
  • Failure to dry stained clothing may result in putrefaction, making it challenging or impossible to determine whether the blood is of human or animal origin. It's advisable to label the stained object with initials and the date. If labelling is not feasible, attaching a tag or similar identifier is necessary.
  • Avoid using air-tight containers to prevent trapped moisture, which can promote bacterial growth and damage the stains. Each garment should be individually wrapped to prevent contact with other clothing, ensuring that no two stains touch each other.
  • Placing a clean sheet of paper between each stain is recommended.
  • All types of stains should be sent to the State Forensic Science Laboratory for examination.

questions.text: A young woman was suspected to have bacterial vaginosis. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?

choices.text: Gardnerella vaginalis is a causative agent
Amsel’s criteria is used for diagnosis
Oral metronidazole is given for treatment

questions.solution:
The false statement about bacterial vaginosis among the following is 'vaginal itching is prominent'.

Bacterial vaginosis is a condition associated with alteration in the normal vaginal flora. There is a decrease in the number of lactobacilli in the vaginal discharge and an increase in other anaerobic bacteria mainly, Gardnerella vaginalis (Mobiluncus and Myco­plasma hominins are others organisms). It is not sexually transmitted. 

About half of the women having bacterial vaginosis are asymptomatic. Symptomatic women mostly present with a profuse, fishy vaginal discharge. It does not cause pruritus, dysuria, and dyspareunia.

Bacterial vaginosis is diagnosed by the Amsel criteria. At least three of the four are needed to confirm the diagnosis

  • White, milky, nonviscous discharge adherent to the vaginal wall.
  • The pH of the discharge more than 4.5. (pH 5-7).
  • Amine or Whiff test-Fishy odour when discharge is mixed with 10% KOH  
  • Presence of clue cells - the epithelial cells have a fuzzy border due to adherence of bacteria.

Oral metronidazole (500 mg twice daily for 7 days) or oral clindamycin (300 mg twice daily for 7 days) is given for the treatment of bacterial vaginosis. Partners do not need to be treated. Metronidazole may be avoided in first trimester.

Indications:

  • Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother
  • Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure
  • Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest
  • Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text: A female patient presents with a throbbing unilateral pulsatile headache of severe intensity, which is aggravated by skipping meals. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of throbbing unilateral headache exacerbated by skipping meals indicates a diagnosis of migraine headache.

Migraine is the second most common cause of headaches, after tension headaches. It is characterized by unilateral and throbbing headaches of moderate to severe intensity. Other features of migraine include deep-seated pain and sensitivity to environmental and sensory stimuli. The headache can be triggered by glares, bright lights, sounds, hunger, stress, physical exertion, hormonal fluctuations during menses, lack of or excess sleep, or alcohol.

Management of migraine includes nonpharmacologic management and pharmacologic measures. Triggers unique to the patient should be avoided. Lifestyle modifications to avoid excessive caffeine and alcohol, and to maintain a healthy sleep cycle are necessary.

Pharmalogical treatment can be divided into abortive treatment of acute attackes and prophylaxis to prevent actue attacks. Acute attack can be treated with acetaminophen, aspirin NSAIDs, antiemetics and triptans. Triptans (Sumatriptan, Zolmitriptan) are used in moderate to severe migraine or when simple analgesics have not been effective. Prophylaxis with beta blockers like propranalol, valproate, topiramate.

Migraine is associated with the release of calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) within the trigeminal nucleus. Hence, newer therapies using CGRP antagonists and monoclonal antibodies to CGRP and its receptor are effective in treating and preventing migraine. They are considered to be as effective as triptans and are better tolerated. 

Other options:

Option A - Cluster headaches are deep, retro-orbital, unilateral, excruciating headaches. They are characterized by attacks at the same time every day. 

Option B - Temporal arteritis or giant cell arteritis is a vasculitis. It affects medium to large-sized arteries. It is characterized by fever, anemia, high erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and headaches in people over the age of 50. 

Option D - Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by excruciating pain in the area of the trigeminal nerve. It lasts for a few seconds to a minute and can recur.
